claims worst situation in sector in 25 years |newspaper=Interfax-Ukraine |date=23 May 2016 |accessdate=16 June 2016}} As of 2016, many of Ukraine's [[Roads in Ukraine|major provincial highways]] are in very poor condition, with an [[Ukravtodor]] official stating that 97% of roads are in need of repair. The road repair budget was set at about 20 billion [[hryvnia]]s, but corruption causes the budget to be poorly spent.{{cite news |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/06/16/ukraines-broken-road-to-europe/ |title=Ukraine's Broken Road to Europe |author=Dan Peleschuk |newspaper=Foreign Policy |date=16 June 2016 |accessdate=17 June 2016}} ===Corruption in higher education=== [[Higher education in Ukraine]] is plagued with bribery.[https://sites.google.com/site/araratosipian/ Osipian, Ararat. (2009). Corruption and Reform in Higher Education in Ukraine. Canadian and International Education Journal, 38(2), pp. 104-122].[https://sites.google.com/site/araratosipian/ Osipian, Ararat. (2007). Higher Education Corruption in Ukraine: Opinions and Estimates. International Higher Education, 49, pp. 20-21].[http://www.politico.eu/article/trading-bribes-for-diplomas-in-ukraines-universities-taxes-transparency-education-corruption/ In Ukraine’s universities, trading bribes for diplomas], [[Politico Europe]] (30 January 2016) In 2011 33% of all students claimed they have encountered corruption in their school, 29% heard about cases of corruption from other students, while 38% had not encountered corruption.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120402110911/http://www.irf.ua/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=32690:one-third-of-students-have-encountered-cases-of-corruption-in-higher-educational-institutions&catid=83:news-edu-en&Itemid=68 One third of students have encountered cases of corruption in higher educational institutions], [[International Renaissance Foundation]] (April 20, 2011) According to Transparency International research done in 2008, 47.3% of university students stated that a bribe had been demanded from them; of those, 29% had paid this bribe freely.''[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/32778/502137 Global Corruption Report 2008]'', [[Transparency International]], Chapter 7.4, p. 280. Students can "buy" a college entry, exam results, marking doctoral and/or master’s theses. Bribes range from US$10 to US$50 for an exam pass to several thousand for entry to a university. According to government sources, bribes vary from US$80 to US$21,500. Salaries of teachers and professors are low in Ukraine compared with other professions; this may cause them to be tempted to demand bribes. According to [[Ararat Osipian]] entire corruption hierarchies have formed in Ukraine's colleges and universities.[https://sites.google.com/site/araratosipian/ Osipian, Ararat. (2009). Corruption Hierarchies in Higher Education in the Former Soviet Bloc. International Journal of Educational Development, 29(3), pp. 321-330]. These hierarchies evolved evolutionary since the 1990s as the result of uncontrolled and rampant corruption.[https://sites.google.com/site/araratosipian/ Osipian, Ararat. (2010). Corrupt Organizational Hierarchies in the Former Soviet Bloc. Transition Studies Review, 17(4), pp. 822-836]. Ararat claims that corrupt ruling regimes control corrupt universities and force them into compliance,[https://sites.google.com/site/araratosipian/ Osipian, Ararat. (2008). Political Graft and Education Corruption in Ukraine: Compliance, Collusion, and Control. Demokratizatsiya: The Journal of Post-Soviet Democratization, 16(4), pp. 323-344]. including during the elections.[https://sites.google.com/site/araratosipian/ Osipian, Ararat. (2010). Corruption in the Politicized University: Lessons for Ukraine’s 2010 Presidential Elections. Innovation: The European Journal of Social Science Research, 23(2), pp. 101-114]. This was aided by universities largely remain Stalinist type bureaucracies, unable to transform.[https://sites.google.com/site/araratosipian/ Osipian, Ararat. (2014). Transforming University Governance in Ukraine: Collegiums, Bureaucracies, and Political Institutions. Higher Education Policy, 27(1), pp. 65-84]. Until 2015 university autonomy was nonexistent.[https://sites.google.com/site/araratosipian/ Osipian, Ararat. (2008). Corruption and Coercion: University Autonomy versus State Control. European Education: Issues and Studies, 40(3), pp. 27-48]. In 2015 the [[Ukrainian parliament]] passed a new law on higher education to give universities more autonomy, including control over their own finances. The aim was to encourage private investment, fundraising and the creation of [[Financial endowment|endowments]]. Ukrainian government officials have been caught with fake university diplomas.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/53259/ Cheating nation] ''Kyiv Post'' (November 19, 2009) ===Corruption and business=== Companies encounter corruption mainly in business licensing, taxation and customs.[http://www.presstv.ir/detail/170602.html Ukraine adopts new anti-corruption bill] [[Press TV]] (March 18, 2011) The [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] has stated corruption is a "significant obstacle" to doing business in Ukraine.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/direct/ukraine/9406824.stm Bribes and bureaucrats: Doing business in Ukraine], [[BBC News]] (7 March 2011) Research conducted by [[Ernst & Young]] in 2011 and 2012 showed that the practice of top managers accepting bribes increased by 9 percent in 2011 and 15 percent in 2012. Another 4 percent were ready to pay bribes in order to hide the details of their financial performance. Politician [[Natalia Korolevska]] has estimated that "Corruption has forced business to go in the shadow where now we have 45% of [[Economy of Ukraine|our economy]]”.[http://www.feg.org.ua/en/news/foundation_press/262.html N. Korolevskaya: Ukraine Needs a Single Anti-Corruption Project], [[Foundation for Effective Governance]] The representative of one [[United Kingdom]]-based company has claimed non-Ukrainian companies often lose contracts if they will not pay bribes or fail to "out-bribe" their competitors. Ukrainians and business representatives have claimed "Business ventures above a certain level require palm-greasing of some functionary at some level". ===Corruption in the social security system=== In 2012 [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] reported that only about 23 percent of social service funds go to those who actually need it. The Ukrainian media have featured many stories revealing that even [[People's Deputy of Ukraine|parliamentarians]] illegally receive social benefits, fraudulently claiming to be war and [[Chernobyl disaster|Chernobyl]] veterans. ===Corruption in healthcare=== Though medical care in state-run hospitals is theoretically free for Ukrainians, patients' paying money there to ensure they receive the treatment required is widespread.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/24/us-ukraine-election-idUSBRE89N0A420121024 Corruption No. 1 problem as Ukraine heads for election], [[Reuters]] (24 October 2012)[https://www.academia.edu/218896/If_I_receive_it_is_a_gift_if_I_demand_it_then_it_is_a_bribe._On_the_local_meaning_of_economic_transactions_in_post-Soviet_Ukraine 'If I receive it, it is a gift; if I demand it, then it is a bribe':On the Local Meaning of Economic Transactions in Post-Soviet Ukraine] by [[Abel Polese]], [[Berghahn Books]] (Winter 2008) In June 2012 advocacy groups accused [[Ministry of Healthcare (Ukraine)|Health Ministry]] officials of embezzling money that should be used to treat [[HIV/AIDS in Ukraine|AIDS patients]] by buying AIDS drugs at hugely inflated prices and then receiving kickbacks.[http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ukraine-corruption-blamed-aids-non-treatment Ukraine:Corruption blamed for AIDS non-treatment], [[Associated Press]] (29 June 2012) ==Costs of corruption== According to Ararat Osipian due to endemic corruption, Ukraine failed to sustain its [[economy of Ukraine#History|economic growth trends]].[https://sites.google.com/site/araratosipian/ Osipian, Ararat. (2009). The Impact of Human Capital on Economic Growth: A Case Study in Post-Soviet Ukraine, 1989-2009. New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 256 p]. The perceived as reckless corruption that marked President Viktor Yanukovich’s rule contributed to [[Viktor Yanukovych#Removal from presidency|his downfall]] in 2014 and left the country’s [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|army]] ill-equipped to counter [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russia’s invasion of Crimea]].{{cite news |last=Zavis |first=Alexandra |date=December 2, 2014 |title=How do countries rank on corruption? |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/europe/la-fg-corruption-rankings-20141203-story.html |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |access-date=November 2, 2015 }} In 2008 Transparency International estimated that 30 to 50 percent of all Ukrainians had faced government corruption. Juhani Grossmann (working for an a.o. [[Management Systems International]] project)[http://old.acrc.org.ua/index.php?lang=en&page=links&id=61 INTERNATIONAL AGENCIES, DONORS, PROJECTS], ANTI-CORRUPTION PORTAL claimed in 2009 that "Ukrainians pay roughly [[Ukrainian hryvnia|₴]]3.5 billion, or more than US$400 million, in bribes annually."[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/44054/print/ Corruption Plague] ''Kyiv Post'' (June 25, 2009).
Since Ukraine has a population of about 45 million, $400 million a year paid in bribes would equate to $9 per person on average. The previous year, he claimed that the figure was US$700 million.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/28537/print/ ''Ukrainians shrug off corruption despite damaging effects''] ''Kyiv Post'' (March 6, 2008).
See also [http://news.kievukraine.info/2008/03/ukrainians-shrug-off-corruption-despite.html blog post] ''Kiev Ukraine News'' Blog, (March 5, 2008). == Government actions == {{See also|European Union Anti-Corruption Initiative in Ukraine}} {{Quote|text=Corruption has become an immediate threat to the [[Human rights in Ukraine|constitutional rights and freedoms of citizens]]. |author=[[Ukrainian President|President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych|Yanukovych]] (April 7, 2011)[http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20110407/163425500.html Ukraine's parliament passes president's anti-corruption law] ''[[RIA Novosti]]'' (April 7, 2011)}} After his [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|election in late 2004]] [[President of Ukraine#List of Presidents of Ukraine|President]] [[Viktor Yushchenko]] promised a "War on Corruption". Several officials were indeed arrested and/or questioned early 2005 (among them later ministers in the [[Azarov Government]] [[Borys Kolesnikov]][http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/57719/ Yanukovych’s inner circle], [[Kyiv Post]] (January 24, 2009)[https://books.google.com/books?id=ebjEVjJ-DcAC&pg=PA580&dq=Borys+Kolesnykov&cd=2#v=onepage&q=Borys%20Kolesnykov&f=false Countries at the crossroads: a survey of democratic governance] by Sanja Tatic & Christopher Walker, [[Rowman & Littlefield Publishers]], 2006, {{ISBN|978-0-7425-5801-4}} (page 580)[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1342327.html Corruption Watch: October 3, 2005], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (October 3, 2005) and [[Yuri Boyko]][http://www.taraskuzio.net/media24_files/8.pdf Gas Lobby Takes Control of Ukrains Secret Service] by [[Taras Kuzio]] (18 March 2010)[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1061677.html Ukraine: Battle Against Corruption Grinds To A Halt], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (September 26, 2005)). Former [[Security Service of Ukraine]] Chairman [[Oleksandr Turchynov]] claimed that in the summer of 2005 Yushchenko prevented an investigation into allegedly fraudulent practices in the transport of [[Turkmenistan|Turkmen]] [[natural gas]] to Ukraine and prevented the arrest of Boyko for [[abuse of office]] while heading [[Naftogaz]]: "Turchynov stated that Yushchenko told him in mid-August to stop 'persecuting my men' and that the investigation of RosUkrEnergo was 'creating a conflict with Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]]'". A survey conducted in November 2008 showed that 73% of people in Ukraine considered the [[second Tymoshenko Government]]'s actions against corruption to be ineffective; comparable figures for the U.S. and the UK were 73% and 39%.Transparency International [http://www.transparency.org/content/download/43788/701097 ''Global Corruption Barometer 2009'' Report], June 2, 2009, {{ISBN|978-3-935711-28-9}} pdf Abs1:22, 32, 33.
In Ukraine, 1200 people were interviewed face to face in a national survey November 4–12, 2008. The survey in the UK was of 1018 people interviewed online November 27 – December 1, 2008. The survey in the U.S. was of 1017 people interviewed online October 30 – November 4, 2008. (pdf ABs1:22). In a survey in 2001, when [[Leonid Kuchma|Kuchma]] was President, 80% of Ukrainians "totally/fairly agreed" with the statement: "The present government has no real interest in punishing corruption". Ukraine joined the [[Group of States Against Corruption]] in 2006.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/117219/ GRECO publishes report on fight against corruption in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (18 November 2011) Over the years, several anti-corruption laws have been passed by the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian parliament]].[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/14258/ Rada passes bill to impose life imprisonment on judges and prosecutors who take large bribes] ''Interfax-Ukraine'' (May 21, 2009)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/62796/ Yanukovych approves postponement of introduction of two anti-corruption laws until January] ''Kyiv Post'' (March 30, 2010)
[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/parliament-adopts-anti-corruption-law/ Parliament adopts anti-corruption law], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (14 April 2013) In September 2011 the [[National Anti-Corruption Committee]] was introduced. Just like his predecessor Yushchenko,[http://www.kommersant.com/p547678/r_1/Viktor_Yushchenko_Attracts_Investments_with_the_War_on_Corruption_/ Viktor Yushchenko Attracts Investments with the War on Corruption] [[Kommersant]] (February 16, 2005) President [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (and his [[Azarov Government]][http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/61479/ Ukraine's prime minister says budget problem hardest], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)) made the fight against corruption a spearhead in his domestic policies.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/112862/ Yanukovych vows to put an end to corruption] ''Kyiv Post'' (September 15, 2011)[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/111586/ Yanukovych: Over 400 officials of current government stand trial] ''Kyiv Post'' (Augustus 25, 2011)[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/96507/ Yanukovych: 'Some misinform international community about Ukraine'] ''Kyiv Post'' (February 7, 2011) Political opponents of Yanukovych have accused him of using his anti-corruption campaign for politically motivated trials; the general public in Ukraine largely shares this view.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1107869.stm Ukraine timeline] [[BBC News]][http://www.euronews.net/2011/10/11/putin-calls-tymoshenko-jail-term-unfair/ Euronews, ''Putin calls Tymoshenko jail term unfair'', 11 October 2011].
[http://www.english.rfi.fr/europe/20111012-yulia-tymoshenko-jail RFI English ''Tymoshenko supporters protest at jail sentence'', by Jan van der Made, 12 October 2011.]
[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/114556/ Amnesty International: Jailed former Ukraine prime minister must be released], ''Kyiv Post'' (11 October 2011)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/114564/ Putin: Tymoshenko verdict unfair], ''Kyiv Post'' (11 October 2011)
[http://www.euronews.net/2011/10/11/eu-feels-let-down-by-ukraine-over-tymoshenko/ EU feels let down by Ukraine over Tymoshenko], [[Euronews]] (11 October 2011)
[http://en.rian.ru/world/20111011/167575875.html Russia and West condemn Tymoshenko verdict], [[RIA Novosti]] (11 October 2011)
[http://en.rian.ru/world/20111012/167597889.html], [[RIA Novosti]] (12 October 2011)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/114656/ Council of Europe concerned about Tymoshenko trial], [[Kyiv Post]] (12 October 2011)The Rating Group undertook a survey of Ukrainian voter's opinions on the [[Yulia Tymoshenko#2011 trial and imprisonment|Yulia Tymoshenko case]]:
46% believed her guilty, 34% not guilty, and 20% were undecided.
26% believed that the case was brought as observance of the law, 54% that it was political persecution, and 20% were undecided.
28% believed that in signing the gas contracts Tymoshenko acted for the benefit of Ukraine, 4% for the benefit of Russia, 44% for her own benefit, and 24% were undecided.
[http://www.ratinggroup.com.ua/en/products/politic/data/entry/13966/ The Rating Group, ''Tymoshenko case through eyes of voters'', 29 September 2011.]
[http://www.ratinggroup.com.ua/upload/files/RG_sprava_Tymoshenko_092011.pdf The Rating Group, ''Справа Тчмощенко Очима Виборцїв'' (Voters' Opinions on the Tymoshenko case), September 2011] President Yanukovych has denied this. Kost Bondarenko, chairman of the board of the Institute of Ukrainian Politics, claims the main sponsors of President Yanukovych's [[Party of Regions]] are unhappy that some Ukrainian politicians have been [[Indictment|criminally charged]] "because they no longer feel above the law". The [[International Association of Anti-Corruption Authorities]] spoke in April 2011 of "remarkable successes in fighting corruption in 2010".[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/business/bus_general/detail/102266/ Ukraine successfully fighting corruption, group says] ''Kyiv Post'' (April 13, 2011) The [[Ambassadors of the European Union|EU Ambassador to Ukraine]], [[Jose Manuel Pinto Teixeira]], stated at an investment conference on February 28, 2012 that Yanukovych's pledges of reform "have regrettably produced no such results." In May, 2014, an Anti-Corruption Initiative was established. In December, it appointed [[Lithuania]]n economist and former [[European Commissioner for Taxation and Customs Union, Audit and Anti-Fraud]] [[Algirdas Šemeta]] as Business [[Ombudsman]].[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/239210.html Former European Taxation Commissioner appointed Business Ombudsman for Ukraine's Anti-Corruption Initiative], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (11 December 2014) The [[National Anti-Corruption Bureau of Ukraine]] was established in June 2014 after its predecessor, the National Anti-Corruption Committee was considered a failure.[http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/864275.shtml Ukraine to set up anti-corruption bureau], [[Global Times]] (6 June 2014) In 2015, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] sacked [[Ihor Kolomoyskyi|Ihor Kolomoisky]] — the billionaire governor of the key industrial region of [[Dnipropetrovsk]]. It came after armed men suspected of links to Kolomoisky briefly occupied the offices of [[Ukrnafta|a state-owned oil firm]] in the capital [[Kiev]].{{cite news |author= |date=March 25, 2015 |title=Ukraine governor Kolomoisky sacked after oil firm row |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32045990 |newspaper=BBC |location=Europe |access-date=November 2, 2015 }} The law on the [[High Anti-Corruption Court of Ukraine]] were cases concerning corruption will be bought directly to this court came into force on 14 June 2018.{{uk icon}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2018/06/13/7183211/ Anticorruption court launched. The CPC claims to be "substituting" the appeal], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (13 June 2018)
[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10144694-ukraine-s-parliament-eventually-passes-law-on-anti-corruption-court.html Ukraine's parliament eventually passes law on anti-corruption court], [[UNIAN]] (7 June 2018)
{{uk icon}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2018/06/7/7182654/ Closed vertical. What is the Higher Anti-Corruption Court and why its creation is afraid of politics?], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (7 June 2018) President Poroshenko expects the court to be established before the end of 2018.[https://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/511967.html Law on High Anti-Corruption Court comes into force], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (14 June 2018) == Extent == According to Ukrainians the most corrupt are the [[Judiciary of Ukraine|judiciary]], the [[Ukrainian police|police]], public servants, the [[Health in Ukraine|health]] service and [[Verkhovna Rada|parliament]].[http://ukrainianweek.com/News/84111 Transparency International Global Corruption Barometer: Ukraine has become more corrupt over the last two years], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (9 July 2013) ===Corruption Perceptions Index ratings=== [[Transparency International]] produces an annual report listing each country's [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] score. This "score relates to perceptions of the degree of corruption as seen by business people and country analysts and, through 2011, ranged between 10 (highly clean) and 0 (highly corrupt)." In the 2010 report, the least corrupt country listed was Denmark with a score of 9.3, and the most corrupt of the 178 countries listed was Somalia with a score of 1.1. From 2012 on, the scores were presented on a 0-100 scale. In the 2016 report, Denmark was still the least corrupt country listed with a score of 90, and Somalia was still the most corrupt of the 176 countries listed, with a score of 10. By comparison, Germany, Luxembourg and the United Kingdom tied as 10th least corrupt countries with a score of 81, and the United States was 18th least corrupt with a score of 74. The following table lists Ukraine's place in the Corruption Perceptions Index table, based on Transparency International's annual reports from 1999 onward. {{Infobox UK legislation |short_title = Crofters' Holdings (Scotland) Act 1886 |type = Act |parliament = Parliament of the United Kingdom |long_title = An Act to amend the Law relating to the Tenure of Land by Crofters in the Highlands and Islands of Scotland, and for other purposes relating thereto |year = 1886 |citation = 49 & 50 Vict., c. 29 |introduced_by = |territorial_extent = [[Scotland]] |royal_assent = 25 June 1886 |commencement = |replaces = |primary_legislation = |amendments = |related_legislation = {{Plainlist}} * [[Landlord and Tenant (Ireland) Act 1870]] * [[Land Law (Ireland) Act 1881]] * [[Representation of the People Act 1884]] {{Endplainlist}} |status = Amended |original_text = |legislation_history = |use_new_UK-LEG = no |UK-LEG_title = |revised_text = |theyworkforyou = |millbankhansard = }} [[File:Crofting Township.jpg|thumb|left|''{{lang|gd|Peighinn Choinnich}}'', crofting town near {{lang|gd|Ùig}} in the [[Isle of Skye]] ]] The '''Crofters Holdings (Scotland) Act 1886''' ({{lang-gd|Achd na Croitearachd 1886}}) is an [[Act of Parliament|Act]] of the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] that created legal definitions of ''crofting parish'' and ''crofter'', granted security of [[land tenure]] to crofters and produced the first [[Crofters Commission]], a land court which ruled on disputes between [[landlord]]s and [[croft (land)|crofters]]. The same court ruled on whether [[parish]]es were or were not crofting parishes. In many respects the Act was modelled on the [[Irish Land Acts]] of [[Landlord and Tenant (Ireland) Act 1870|1870]] and [[Land Law (Ireland) Act 1881|1881]].{{Cite book |title=Land, Faith and the Crofting Community: Christianity and Social Criticism in the Highlands of Scotland 1843–1893 |last=MacColl |first=Allan W. |publisher=Edinburgh University Press |year=2006 |isbn=9780748626748 |pages=179 }} By granting the crofters security of tenure, the Act put an end to the [[Highland Clearances]].Thomson: ''The Companion to Gaelic Scotland.'' 1983, p. 237 The Act was largely a result of crofters' agitation which had become well organised and very persistent in [[Skye]] and of growing support, throughout the [[Scottish Highlands|Highlands]], for the [[Crofters Party]], which had gained five [[member of parliament|members of parliament]] in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1885|general election]] of 1885. Agitation took the form of [[rent strike]]s (withholding rent payments) and occupying land which the landlords had reserved for hunting or sheep. The Act itself did not quell the agitation. In particular it was very weak in terms of enabling the Crofters Commission to resolve disputes about access to land. It was enough however to make much more acceptable, politically, the use of troops in confrontations with agitators.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/644246228|title=Labour and Scottish nationalism|last=1950-|first=Keating, Michael,|date=1979|publisher=Macmillan|others=Bleiman, David,|isbn=1349046787|location=London|oclc=644246228}} The Act was not fully effective in increasing the equality of land distribution in Scotland. By the year 2000, two-thirds of Scotland's land area was still owned by only 1 252 landowners out of a population of 5 million.Wightman: ''Scotland: Land and Power.'' 2000, p. 23–29 (figures are for 2000) ==Background== During the [[Highland Clearances]], the crofters had no official rights to the land; until 1886, it was legal to evict any crofter at the landlord's convenience. The Land Wars commenced in Scotland in 1874 with the successful legal case of the [[Bernera Riot]] on the island of Great Bernera in the Outer Hebrides. The crofters wanted recognition of their traditional rights to the land that they had enjoyed under the [[Scottish clans|clan system]] from the [[Middle Ages]].Hunter: ''The making of the crofting community''. 1976, p. 219 Through political and economic development the gentry began to take an alternate perspective on their tenantry:
The cultural force of ''{{lang|gd|dùthchas}}'' [heritage] was pervasive in Gaeldom and was central to the social cohesion of the clan because it articulated the expectations of the masses that the ruling family had the responsibility to act as their protectors and guarantee secure possession of land in return for allegiance, military service, tribute and rental. It was a powerful and enduring belief which lived on long after the military rationale of clanship itself had disappeared and tribal chiefs had shed their ancient responsibilities and become commercial landlords.Devine: ''Clanship to Crofters' War.'' 1993, p. 11
Land agitation in Scotland began because of the "Home Rule" movement in Ireland and information and opinions of this movement brought by fishermen to the [[Outer Hebrides]]. Believed that they were the rightful owners of the land, crofters used [[rent strike]]s and what came to be known as land raids: crofter occupations of land to which crofters believed they should have access for common grazing or for new crofts, but which landlords had given over to sheep farming and hunting parks (called deer forests).{{fact|date=February 2016}} The strife grew more intense; the landlords hired warships for protection from the crofters. From time to time there were open uprisings and riots. In 1884 [[Representation of the People Act 1884|suffrage was extended]] to men owning land worth at least [[pound sterling|£]]10 or paying £10 in rent annually. This included many Highland crofters.{{cite web |last1=Crowley |first1=D.W. |title=The Crofters’ Party, 1885 to 1892 — The first British independent common people’s political party |url=http://www.caledonia.org.uk/land/documents/Crofters%27%20Party.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=24 April 2017 }} At a political level the crofters wanted legal rights, so the ''{{lang|gd|Comunn Gàidhealach Ath-Leasachadh an Fhearainn}}'' ('Highland Land Law Reform Association') was established in 1885 in [[London]]. The [[Crofters' Party]] was established and elected five MPs in 1885. ''{{lang|gd|Is Treasa Tuath na Tighearna}}'' ('The people are stronger than the lord') was their best-known slogan. The government feared that the "Home Rule" movement would spread to the {{lang|gd|[[Gàidhealtachd]]}} (Gaelic-speaking areas in Scotland) from Ireland. The [[Napier Commission]] interviewed crofters all over the {{lang|gd|Gàidhealtachd}} and made careful study of the crofters' position, publishing its report in 1884. [[William Gladstone]] tried to pass a new law granting crofters more rights, but it was voted down in May 1885. Gladstone left his post in 1885 but the other parties created a new government. Gladstone returned to power in January 1886, and the act was finally passed 25 June 1886. ==The Act== For the first time in [[Scottish history]], the Crofting Act of 1886 affirmed the rights of crofters to their land. It also granted a legal status to crofting towns.Hunter: ''The making of the crofting community.'' 1976, p. 206 The Act dealt with the following points especially: * It gave [[security of tenure]] to the crofters, as long as they worked the croft and paid the rent. * Crofters had the right to pass down their croft to their descendants. * Crofters had the right to be paid for land improvements, such as erecting fences and drainage * A standard of reasonable rent was established and required. * The first [[Crofters' Commission]] was established. * Crofters had the opportunity to reassess the rent with the Crofters' Commission. The Act specified eight [[shires of Scotland|counties of Scotland]] as counties where parishes might be recognised as crofting parishes: [[Argyll]], [[Caithness]], [[Cromartyshire|Cromarty]], [[Inverness-shire|Inverness]], [[Orkney]], [[Ross-shire|Ross]], [[Shetland]], and [[Sutherland]]. Within these counties a crofting parish was a parish where there were year-by-year [[tenant farmer|tenant]]s of land (tenants without leases) who were paying less than £30 a year in rent and who had possessed effective common [[grazing rights]] during the 80 years since 24 June 1806.{{Cite web|url=https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/49-50/29/contents|title=Crofters Holdings (Scotland) Act 1886|website=www.legislation.gov.uk|language=en|others=Expert Participation|access-date=2018-02-01}} The Crofters' Commission also was in charge of establishing [[fair rent]] and reevaluating rents every seven years. If crofters believed that the rent was too high they had the opportunity to go to the commission. Quite often the rents were lowered or even removed, if the crofters had already been paying too much.Hunter: ''The making of the crofting community.'' 1976, p. 225 The Commission had the power to reform the Act and establish other Acts, as well as grant green land to crofters in order to enlarge small crofts. ==Results== There were different opinions about the Act. On the one hand crofters complained that the Act did not go far enough, because they were not granted automatic right to fertile land for expansion of their small crofts. Worse, the Act did not delineate the position of [[cotter (farmer)|cotters]], who had never had land. After a while, they saw that the Commission was willing to protect their rights, especially with regard to [[rent security]]. Unfortunately, the Commission was underfunded and there was not enough land to distribute to crofters. The Act did not resolve the greatest complaint of the crofters, that the land should be returned to them. There was no resolution of the issue where landlords and crofters wanted the same piece of land. Thomson: ''The Companion to Gaelic Scotland.'' 1983, p. 237 On the other hand, the landlords said that there was "communism looming in the future" and ''[[The Scotsman]]'' wrote that the Act was a "great infringement on the rights of private property.'"Hunter: ''The making of the crofting community.'' 1976, p. 225 The Act did not end the land agitation, because [[Arthur Balfour]] believed that the Act gave moral authority to the authorities to quell every uprising to reestablish "law and order."Hunter: ''The making of the crofting community.'' 1976, p. 228 For this reason, warships were sent to the Isle of Skye and [[Tiree]]. In the years after the Act, ''{{lang|gd|Comunn Gàidhealach Ath-Leasachadh an Fhearainn}}'' (now called ''{{lang|gd|Dionnasg an Fhearainn}}'', "the Land League") and the Crofters' Party the political influence that they had had, because they could not agree on the issue of land and how far to follow the "Home Rule" movement in Ireland on the issue of land ownership. This opinion was raised again in the [[Crofting Act 1976]] in which crofters gained the legal right to purchase their land for fifteen years' rent. However, by owning their own land, crofters lost the right to CCAGS (''Crofting Counties Agricultural Grant Scheme''). In the [[Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2003]] the right of purchase was given to community organizations even against the will of landowners, to advance social and economic development. The [[Crofting Reform (Scotland) Act 2010]] granted equality between tenants and landowners, especially with regard to grants and obligations and clarified the details of residency requirements. Now, tenants or owners must live within {{convert|32|km|abbr=in}} of the croft. Crofts not in use may be granted to new tenants. Looking back in history, Hunter believes that the Act established an old-fashioned order, with a place for the tenantry quite different than as in Ireland where crofters could buy their land under "Home Rule" acts. The Act was neither effective in the development of crofting communities nor did it encompass the political and social beliefs of those communities.Hunter: ''The making of the crofting community.'' 1976, p. 283 But according to [[Andy Wightman|Wightman]], the Act paved the road to further land development in Scotland, although it did not affect areas outside the {{lang|gd|Gàidhealtachd}}. Wightman also stated that the "land question" has yet to be resolved, as two-thirds of Scotland's land area is still owned by only 1 252 landowners out of a population of 5 million.Wightman: ''Scotland: Land and Power.'' 2000, p. 23–29 (figures are for 2000) ==See also== * [[Highland Clearances]] * [[Highland Potato Famine]] * [[History of Scotland#Rural life|History of Scotland § Rural life]] ==Citations== {{Reflist}} == References == * {{cite book |first=T. M. |last=Devine |authorlink=Tom Devine |title=Clanship to Crofters' War: The Social Transformation of the Scottish Highlands |publisher=Manchester Univ Press |location=Manchester |date=1993}} * {{cite book |first=James |last=Hunter |title=The making of the crofting community (Revised edition 2000) |publisher=John Donald |location=Edinburgh |year=1976 |isbn=0-85976-537-7}} * {{cite book |first=Derick S. |last=Thomson |authorlink=Derick S. Thomson |title=The Companion to Gaelic Scotland |publisher=Basil Blackwater Publisher Lim., [[Àth nan Damh]] |year=1983 |isbn= 0-631-12502-7}} * {{cite book |first=Andy |last=Wightman |authorlink=Andy Wightman |title=Scotland: Land and Power |publisher=Luath Press Lim., Dùn Èideann |year=2000 |isbn=0-946487-70-7}} * {{cite journal |first=Ian |last=Bradley |url=http://www.historytoday.com/ian-bradley/having-and-holding-highland-land-war-1880s |title='Having and Holding': The Highland Land War of the 1880s |work=[[History Today]] |date=December 1987 |volume=37 |issue=12 |pages=23–28}} ==External links== *{{UK-LEG|path=ukpga/Vict/49-50/29}} {{UK legislation}} [[Category:Crofting]] [[Category:Acts of the Parliament of the United Kingdom concerning Scotland]] [[Category:United Kingdom Acts of Parliament 1886]] [[Category:History of Orkney]] [[Category:History of Shetland]] [[Category:History of the Outer Hebrides]] [[Category:History of the Scottish Highlands]] [[Category:History of Argyll and Bute]] [[Category:1886 in Scotland]] [[Category:Highland Estates]] [[Category:Highlands and Islands of Scotland]] [[Category:Agriculture legislation in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Land law]]

{{Infobox architect |birth_name=David Randall Hertz |nationality=American |birth_date={{birth date|1960|10|6}} |birth_place=[[Los Angeles, California]] |practice=Studio of Environmental Architecture |significant_buildings=[[747 Wing House]] }}
'''David Randall Hertz''' (born October 6, 1960) is an [[United States|American]] [[architect]], inventor and educator. He is known for his work in [[sustainable architecture]] and as an early innovator in the development of [[recycled]] building materials.
== Biography == David Hertz got his start in architecture at a young age. In high school Hertz often sneaked into construction sites because of his interest in building. After being caught by a property owner, he was introduced to the building's designer, famed Los Angeles architect [[John Lautner]]. Hertz then apprenticed under Lautner for four years. After receiving a degree from the [[Southern California Institute of Architecture]] in 1980, Hertz went on to work in the office of [[Frank Gehry]] before founding his own firm, Syndesis, in 1983.<ref>http://installationmag.com/looking-back-looking-ahead-sci-arc-40/</ref> That year, Hertz developed "Syndecrete," a form of concrete which incorporates post-consumer and industrial waste such as [[polypropylene]] carpet fibers and [[fly ash]], and is lighter weight than traditional concrete, and may have other waste products such as wood, crushed glass, or plastic chips added for decoration.<ref>Popular Science, Oct 1990, pg 54 https://books.google.com/books?id=lQEAAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA54&ots=2SQUCu1jom&dq=syndecrete%20magazine&pg=PA54#v=onepage&q&f=false</ref> Syndecrete was included in the [[MoMA]] show "Mutant Materials in Contemporary Design" in 1995.<ref>Mutant Materials in Contemporary Design, Museum of Modern Art, New York, NY, 1995 (First Edition) {{ISBN|0870701312}}</ref>
In 2004, he became [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design]] accredited.<ref>http://www.usgbc.org/organizations/david-hertz-architect-inc?view=employees</ref> In 2007 he founded the architectural firm S.E.A., the [http://studioea.com Studio of Environmental Architecture], based in [[Venice Beach, California]], which has an emphasis in environmentally sustainable buildings, making use of high efficiency light and water systems, as well as solar panels and solar water heating.<ref>http://www.smgbc.org/participants.htm</ref> In 2008 Hertz was elected to the prestigious College of Fellows of The [[American Institute of Architects]] as the youngest member in its 152-year history.<ref>[http://dht.dwell.com/homes/mckinely-residence Dwell Home Tours<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> His architectural and material work has been exhibited internationally.<ref>http://www.ga-ada.co.jp/japanese/ga_gallery/2006/0603-05_GAH2006/gallery_gah2006.html</ref><ref>http://europeanarch.blogspot.com/2013/06/the-city-and-world-exhibition.html</ref>
Hertz currently is involved with the construction of environmentally beneficial residences and commercial buildings, primarily in and around [[Venice, California]] with his company Studio of Environmental Architecture, as well as promoting sustainability, including a presentation at TEDx in 2013.<ref>http://www.ted.com/tedx/events/9745</ref> In 2014, residences he designed and built were featured in Los Angeles [[American Institute of Architects]] (AIA) Monograph Tour.<ref>http://www.aialosangeles.org/calendar/hertz-monograph-tour#.VS7o4ytdWAc</ref> In 2015, he was featured in [[KCRW]]'s Art Talk in the episode titled "Daring and Inspirational Architecture Around the World."<ref>http://www.kcrw.com/news-culture/shows/art-talk/daring-inspirational-architecture-around-the-world</ref> In 2016, he spoke at the Greenbuild Expo in Los Angeles on historical and cutting edge techniques of extracting drinking water from the air.<ref>https://greenbuildexpo.com/Attendee/Conference/SpeakerDetails?id=571338</ref>
Most recently, ORO Editions has published a monograph titled "The Restorative Home: Ecological Houses by David Hertz" which focuses on residential homes built throughout his career.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Webb|first1=Michael|title=The Restorative Home: Ecological Houses by David Hertz|date=2015|publisher=ORO Editions|isbn=9781941806692|edition=1}}</ref> Hertz is also working to promote widespread adoption of [[atmospheric water generator]] technology with Skywater, using his machine in [[Venice, California]] to provide drinking water and water for local community gardens.<ref>http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/07/04/david-hertzs-skywater</ref> He and his wife Laura Doss-Hertz have also partnered with the [[GO Campaign]] to fund sustainable water projects around the world.<ref>https://www.gocampaign.org/initiatives/go-water/</ref> Hertz founded The Skysource/Skywater Alliance team which was selected from 98 teams from 27 countries for the Grand Prize of the Water Abundance XPRIZE having made more than 2,000 liters of water in 24 hours using 100% renewable energy at a cost of less than 2 cents/ liter. <ref> https://www.xprize.org/articles/waxp-grand-prize-winner </ref> In April 2017, Hertz sold his home residence for $14.6 million USD<ref>http://www.latimes.com/business/realestate/hot-property/la-fi-hotprop-californication-house-venice-record-20170424-story.html</ref> [[File:747 Wing House Photo by Carson Leh.jpg|thumb|747 Wing House]]
== Notable projects == Completed in 2003, Hertz's home residence took was built in two phases, and consists of four structures connected by enclosed bridges, in a style inspired by Balinese architecture. The building was designed as a testbed for many of his environmentally conscious building ideas, such as rooftop solar heating panels for water, [[radiant heating]], sustainable woods used throughout, and extensive use of his custom concrete, Syndecrete, which uses recycled industrial and post-consumer waste.<ref>http://www.dwell.com/my-house/article/sustainability-stages</ref> Additionally, the large Syndecrete walls are designed to work as a solar sink, absorbing the sun's heat during the day and slowly release it at night.<ref>http://www.latimes.com/style/la-hm-chexcerpt30jun30-story.html#page=1</ref> The house was regularly used as a location in the series [[Californication (TV series)]].
The [[Mullin Automotive Museum]], located in [[Oxnard, California]], was completed in 2010, and holds the car collection of philanthropist [[Peter W. Mullin]].<ref>http://www.kcrw.com/news-culture/shows/art-talk/hot-and-cool-reasons-to-go-to-oxnard-and-laguna</ref> Hertz renovated the 50,000 sq, ft building which previously held the Otis Chandler Transportation Museum, and added features such as [[solar panels]] and a rooftop garden to make the building more environmentally sustainable, while also including new and vintage [[Art Deco]] elements in the decorations throughout, to keep in tune with the collection of 1920's and '30s automobiles.<ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jay-weston/new-mullin-automotive-mus_b_568188.html</ref>
In 2011, Hertz completed his most ambitious and widely recognized project to date. The [[747 Wing House]] was built from a mothballed [[Boeing 747-100]] in the [[Santa Monica]] mountains. The project was extremely complex and called for using a [[CH-47 Chinook]] cargo helicopter to transport sections of the plane to the building site.<ref>Amelar, Sarah. ''Come Fly With Me''. Architectural Record, 2012, p. 84.</ref><ref>[http://studioea.com/profile/ David Hertz FAIA, Studio of Environmental Architecture, Green Buildings, Sustainable Design, Venice Beach, Los Angeles, California | Profile<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> By making use of large sections of prefabricated material, he was able to reduce the greenhouse emissions that would have been required to bring raw materials and remove waste material.
Another example of Hertz's creative use of unusual building materials is the "Panel House," in [[Venice Beach, California]], so named because of its use of industrial refrigerator panels to provide insulation.<ref>http://inhabitat.com/touring-the-panel-house/</ref> Designed for the owner of a company that manufactures automobile washing equipment, the house was constructed like a miniature sky-scraper, utilizing a heavy metal frame in poured-concrete base, making weight-bearing walls unnecessary and allowing for large, automated windows which provide ocean views from almost anywhere in the house.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/13/garden/13clean.html?_r=0&pagewanted=all</ref> In 2009, the house earned the Chicago Athenaeum Museum of Architecture and Design's American Architecture Award.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.optimaweb.com/pdfs/2009_AMERICAN_ARCH_AWARDS.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323175233/http://www.optimaweb.com/pdfs/2009_AMERICAN_ARCH_AWARDS.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-23 |df= }}</ref>
In 2018, Hertz along with a team called the Skysource/Skywater Alliance <ref>https://water.xprize.org/prizes/water-abundance/teams/the_skysource_skywater_alliance</ref> won the XPRIZE Water Abundance competition <ref>https://water.xprize.org/prizes/water-abundance/articles/the-path-to-a-water-abundance-xprize-winner</ref> by achieving the foundation's goal of producing at least 2,000 liters of water in a single day for no more than two cents per liter.
==Projects<ref>{{cite book|last1=Webb|first1=Michael|title=The Restorative Home: Ecological Houses by David Hertz|date=2015|publisher=ORO Editions|isbn=9781941806692|edition=1}}</ref>== * Red Rock Canyon House, Red Rock Canyon, NV - 1983 * Venable Studio, Venice, CA - 1989 * Stradella Road House, Bel Air, CA - 1994 * Californication House, Venice, CA - 1995 * Residence on Cold Creek, Malibu, CA - 1995 * Bay Residence, Brentwood, CA - 1997 * Tilt Up Slab House, Venice, CA - 1999 * Floating House, Venice, CA - 2000 * House on Horizon Hill, Yachats, OR - 2001 * Le Brun Residence, Mar Vista, CA - 2003 * Panel House, Venice CA - 2003 * Dreyfus/Hall Residence, Montecito CA - 2004 * Split House, Venice, CA - 2005 * Slat House, Marina Del Rey, CA - 2005 * Mesa Road House, Santa Monica, CA - 2006 * Beverly Grove, Beverly Hills, CA - 2006 * Californication House Phase II, Venice, CA - 2006 * Lee Residence, Pasadena, CA - 2006 * East Canal House, Venice, CA - 2007 * Boone Residence, Venice, CA - 2008 * Strand Residence, Manhattan Beach, CA - 2008 * Adelaide Residence, Santa Monica, CA - 2011 * Yale House, Santa Monica, CA - 2011 * Hermosa House, Hermosa Beach, CA - 2011 * Navy and Pacific House, Venice CA, 2012 * Linda Rosa Residence, La Jolla, CA - 2012 * 747 Wing House, Malibu CA - 2013 * Butterfly House, Venice CA - 2013
== Awards == ===2018=== *XPRIZE Water Abundance Competition Grand Prize Winner <ref>https://water.xprize.org/prizes/water-abundance/articles/the-path-to-a-water-abundance-xprize-winner</ref>
===2015=== *Best of the Westside: Best Architecture Firm, awarded by 'The Argonaut' magazine <ref>http://argonautnews.com/best-of-the-westside-services/</ref>
===2014=== *AIA Los Angeles Monograph Tour of Venice Beach Residences <ref>http://aialosangeles.businesscatalyst.com/calendar/hertz-monograph-tour#.WJUZchMrKL4</ref>
=== 2012 === * The Chicago Athenaeum American Architecture Award 2012 for the 747 Wing House<ref>https://chi-athenaeum.org/assets/pdf_archives/amerarc/archive-2012-American-Arch-awards.pdf</ref> * AIA California Council Residential Design Awards 2012 for 747 Wing House <ref>Home and Architectural Trends, Volume 29, No 2, April 2013, pg 33 http://issuu.com/trendsideas/docs/us2902</ref><ref>http://www.aiacc.org/2012/11/06/announcing-the-2012-residential-award-recipients/</ref> * The International Design Awards 2012 Gold for 747 Wing House<ref>http://idesignawards.com/winners/catwinner2010.php?compName=ARCHITECTURE&level=pro&compNum=IDA%2012</ref>
=== 2010 === * Selected for inclusion in :California Design Biennial. PMCA Pasadena Museum of Contemporary Art Action / Reaction<ref>http://www.kcrw.com/news-culture/shows/design-and-architecture/action-reaction-design-and-transformation</ref>
=== 2008 === * Elected to the College of Fellows of the American Institute of Architects<ref>http://archrecord.construction.com/news/daily/archives/080219aia.asp</ref><ref>https://archrecord.construction.com/news/daily/archives/080219aia.asp {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130327193645/https://archrecord.construction.com/news/daily/archives/080219aia.asp |date=March 27, 2013 }}</ref>

The '''Government Performance Coalition''' was created in 1999 by a group of organizations and researchers with the goal of presenting the [[President of the United States]], government managers, [[United States Congress|Congress]], the media, and the public views on the improvement of government management.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.seagov.org/initiatives/other.shtml|title=Performance Reporting for Government—Reporting initiatives|website=www.seagov.org|access-date=2018-08-02}}</ref> The coalition maintains that it seeks to ensure a continued focus and attention to performance and management issues and to identify existing issues that need new attention, and refine past efforts and highlight related governance policies that affect performance.<ref>Mission statement from Government Performance Coalition Website: http://www.govresults.com/</ref> The Coalition, comprising nearly two dozen organizations, meets regularly in Washington, D.C. to serve as a clearinghouse for its individual members’ respective agendas regarding government management improvement. During presidential election years, the Coalition sponsors events to highlight the importance of good government management issues in the campaign and to prepare materials that would be helpful to the winning candidate’s incoming political appointees.
==Resource development== The Coalition was initially formed to develop resource materials to support the eventual winner of the 2000 presidential campaign. In that effort, it sponsored a series of forums on key management issues, such as [[human capital]], [[Finance|financial management]], and [[performance management]]. These forums and associated recommendations were compiled into a report given to the incoming administration for President George W. Bush. In a memorandum dated December 20, 2000, the coalition identified critical issues that require new policy directions such as the high-risk areas in the General Accounting Office (e.g. [[Federal Aviation Administration|FAA]], [[United States Department of Defense|DOD]] financial management, [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]], [[Housing and Urban Development Corporation|HUD]], student aid, superfund, [[NASA]]).<ref>{{Cite book|title=Memos to the President: Management Advice from the Nation's Top Public Administrators|last=Abramson|first=Mark|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2001|isbn=0742522393|location=Lanham|pages=14}}</ref> Many of the recommendations were subsequently used to frame his [[President's Management Agenda]].
In 2008, the Coalition members, both individually and collectively, sponsored a series of forums in 2008 with recommendations to the incoming Obama Administration to place an appropriate emphasis on performance. It recommended three broad initiatives: 1) implement a performance-based framework at agencies; 2) invest more in federal human resources; and, 3) mandate the use of innovation and technology to revolutionize government.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.govexec.com/oversight/2008/12/obama-urged-to-focus-on-performance-based-government/28197/|title=Obama urged to focus on performance-based government|work=Government Executive|access-date=2018-08-02}}</ref> Barack Obama’s fiscal year 2010 budget has a section titled “Building a High-Performance Government,” with its first item being “Putting Performance First.”<ref>Office of Management and Budget, "The President's Fiscal Year 2010 Budget," ''Analytical Perspectives,'' "Building a High-Performance Government," Washington, DC (2009). http://www.whitehouse.gov/omb/budget/fy2010/assets/building.pdf. Retrieved 06-30-09.</ref>
==Projects== The Coalition members jointly sponsored the publication of a book as part of the 2004 presidential transition. That book, “Getting Results: A Guide for Federal Leaders and Managers”<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=fPDHRFxxJEoC&lpg=PP1&ots=DRGPHYKWqX&dq=Getting%20Results%3A%20A%20Guide%20for%20Federal%20Leaders%20and%20Managers&pg=PP1 White, Barry, and Kathryn Newcomer, eds., "Getting Results: A Guide for Federal Leaders and Managers," Management Concepts and the George Washington University Center for Public Service Innovation (Washington, DC) 2005</ref> was an orientation guide provided to incoming political appointees to help them be successful managers in the federal government. The coalition, through the Performance Institute, also trains thousands of government managers every year on performance-based topics as well as methodologies and best practices for transparency and citizen services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.performanceinstitute.org/about-us/about/|title=About - The Performance Institute|work=The Performance Institute|access-date=2018-08-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
A February 2009 article in [[Government Executive magazine]] described the Coalition as “An unfunded organization with no professional staff, the coalition is run through the volunteer efforts of good government group leaders. Early in the Bush administration, the coalition received some funding for a joint book project on performance management advice, but it now operates primarily as a clearinghouse for its member organizations' efforts.” The article continues: “The loose structure isn't just a vehicle for agreement at the coalition. It's a requirement. Because of the variety of governance structures among the member groups, it's impossible for them all to commit to a concerted lobbying campaign or even formally endorse a program.”<ref>Rosenberg, Alyssa. “Gathering Good,” ''Government Executive'', February 2009: http://www.govexec.com/story_page.cfm?filepath=/features/0209-01/0209-01s3.htm&oref=search</ref>
==Members of the Government Performance Coalition==
The members of Government Performance Coalition include: [[American Society for Public Administration]], [[Association of Government Accountants]], Cisco Internet Business Solutions Group, The Public Sector Consortium, [[CNA Corporation]], Coalition for Effective Change, Trachtenberg School of Public Policy and Public Administration at George Washington University, [[Grant Thornton]], [[IBM Center for The Business of Government]], [[International Brotherhood of Teamsters]], American University Institute for the Study of Policy Implementation, Management Concepts, [[Mercatus Center]] at George Mason University, [[National Academy of Public Administration (United States)]], [[Partnership for Public Service]], [[The Performance Institute]], and Senior Executives Association.{{Cn|date = August 2015}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = | header_align = left/right/center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left/right/center | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Flag of Canada.svg | width1 = 300 | caption1 = [[Flag of Canada|National flag of Canada]], 1965–present | alt1 = | image2 = Canadian Red Ensign 1957-1965.svg | width2 = 300 | caption2 = 1957 version of the [[Canadian Red Ensign]] that had evolved as the ''de facto'' national flag until 1965 | alt2 = }} The '''Great Canadian Flag Debate''' (or '''Great Flag Debate''') was a national debate that took place in 1963 and 1964 when a new design for the [[flag of Canada|national flag of Canada]] was chosen.{{cite web|url=http://www.canadashistory.ca/Magazine/Online-Extension/Articles/The-Great-Flag-Debate|title=The Great Flag Debate|last=Levine|first=Allan|date=|website=Canada's History|publisher=|access-date=}} Although the flag debate had been going on for a long time prior, it officially began on June 15, 1964, when [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Lester B. Pearson]] proposed his plans for a new flag in the [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]]. The debate lasted more than six months, bitterly dividing{{cite book | title=The Flags of Canada | author=Fraser, A.B. | year=1998 | at=Chapter V}} the people in the process. The debate over the proposed new Canadian flag was ended by [[cloture|closure]] on December 15, 1964. It resulted in the adoption of the "[[Flag of Canada|Maple Leaf]]" as the Canadian national flag. The flag was inaugurated on February 15, 1965, and since 1996, February 15 has been commemorated as [[National Flag of Canada Day]]. == Background == {{refimprove|section|date=December 2016}} [[File:John A Macdonald election poster 1891.jpg|200px|thumb|An 1891 election poster featuring Macdonald and the undefaced Red Ensign]] === Union Jack and Red Ensign === For much of its [[Canadian Confederation|post-Confederation]] history, Canada used both the [[Union Flag|Royal Union Flag]] (Union Jack) as its national flag, and the [[Canadian Red Ensign]] as a popularly recognized and distinctive Canadian flag. The first Canadian Red Ensigns were used in Prime Minister Sir [[John A. Macdonald]]'s time. The Governor General at the time of Macdonald's death, [[Frederick Stanley, 16th Earl of Derby|Lord Stanley]], wrote to London in 1891:
... the Dominion Government has encouraged by precept and example the use on all public buildings throughout the provinces of the Red Ensign with the Canadian badge on the fly... [which] has come to be considered as the recognized flag of the Dominion, both ashore and afloat.
Under pressure from pro-imperial public opinion, Prime Minister Sir [[Wilfrid Laurier]] raised the Union Flag over Parliament, where it remained until the re-emergence of the Red Ensign in the 1920s. In 1945, Prime Minister [[William Lyon Mackenzie King]], having flown the Union Jack over Parliament throughout the war, made the Canadian Red Ensign the official Canadian flag by [[Order in Council]]. Mackenzie King also tried to give Canada a new flag. The recommendation that came back was a Red Ensign, but substituting the coat of arms of Canada with a gold maple leaf. Mackenzie King stopped the venture. [[File:Canflagcartoon.jpg|thumb|300px|left|[[Anti-Quebec sentiment|Anti-francophone]] political cartoon c. 1910 entitled ''The next favor. 'A flag to suit the minority.''' satirising the minority rights of Francophone Canadians by showing the [[French tricolor]] given greater prominence than the [[Union Jack]] and the maple leaf surrounded by two [[fleurs-de-lis]].]] In 1958, an extensive poll was taken of the attitudes that adult Canadians held toward the flag. Of those who expressed opinions, over 80% wanted a national flag entirely different from that of any other nation, and 60% wanted their flag to bear the [[maple leaf]].{{cite web|title= Dataset: Canadian Gallup Poll, August 1958, #270|url=http://odesi1.scholarsportal.info/webview/index.jsp?v=2&submode=variable&study=http%3A%2F%2F142.150.190.11%3A80%2Fobj%2FfStudy%2Fcipo-270-E-1958-08&gs=10F1&variable=http%3A%2F%2F142.150.190.11%3A80%2Fobj%2FfVariable%2Fcipo-270-E-1958-08_V51&mode=documentation&top=yes|website=odesi1.scholarsportal.info|accessdate=21 January 2018}} === Lester B. Pearson === [[File:1946 Canadian flag proposal.svg|thumb|200px|right|The 1946 special joint committee's recommended national flag]] [[File:Native Sons of Canada Flag.svg|thumb|200px|right|The flag promoted by the Native Sons of Canada{{Cite episode |title=The Canadian Scene: A Special Report |url=http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/politics/language-culture/the-great-canadian-flag-debate/maple-leaf-flag-campaign.html |series=CBC News Magazine |serieslink=CBC News Magazine |first=Norman |last=DePoe |author-link=Norman DePoe |network=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] |date=28 December 1958 |accessdate=17 February 2014}}]] From his office as [[Leader of the Official Opposition (Canada)|leader of the opposition]], Lester Pearson issued a press release on January 27, 1960, in which he summarized the problem and presented his suggestion as:
... Canadian Government taking full responsibility as soon as possible for finding a solution to the flag problem, by submitting to Parliament a measure which, if accepted by the representatives of the people in Parliament, would, I hope, settle the problem.
The [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|Progressive Conservative]] government of the time, headed by Prime Minister [[John Diefenbaker]], did not accept the invitation to establish a new Canadian flag, so Pearson made it [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party]] policy in 1961, and part of the party's election platform in the [[Canadian federal election, 1962|1962]] and [[Canadian federal election, 1963|1963 federal elections]]. During the election campaign of 1963, Pearson promised that Canada would have a new flag within two years of his election. No previous party leader had ever gone as far as Pearson did, by putting a time limit on finding a new national flag for Canada. The 1963 election brought the Liberals back to power, but with a minority government. In February 1964, a three-leaf design was leaked to the press. [[File:Canada Pearson Pennant 1964.svg|200px|thumb|right|Lester Pearson's preferred choice for a new flag was nicknamed "the Pearson Pennant".]] At the 20th [[Royal Canadian Legion]] Convention in [[Winnipeg]] on May 17, 1964, Pearson faced an unsympathetic audience of Canadian Legionnaires and told them that the time had come to replace the Canadian Red Ensign with a distinctive maple leaf flag.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/insight/2015/02/14/canadas-maple-leaf-flag-born-amid-bitter-debate.html|title=Leader Lester Pearson wanted a flag to represent the new, multicultural Canada. John Diefenbaker was vehemently opposed. The battle was ferocious.|last=Hunter|first=Paul|date=2015-02-14|newspaper=The Toronto Star|issn=0319-0781|access-date=2016-03-23}} The Royal Canadian Legion and the Canadian Corps Association wanted to make sure that the new flag would include the Union Flag as a sign of Canadian ties to the United Kingdom and to other [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] countries, such as [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], that use the Union Flag in the quarter of their national flag. Lester Pearson's preferred choice for a new flag was nicknamed "the Pearson Pennant". Pearson’s first design featured the three maple leaves on a blue background. Pearson preferred this choice, as the blue bars reflected Canada's motto, "From Sea to Sea". ==Parliamentary debate begins== === Opening resolution === On June 15, 1964, Pearson opened the parliamentary flag debate with a resolution: {{cquote|… to establish officially as the flag of Canada a flag embodying the emblem proclaimed by His Majesty King [[George V]] on November 21, 1921 — three maple leaves conjoined on one stem — in the colours red and white then designated for Canada, the red leaves occupying a field of white between vertical sections of blue on the edges of the flag.}} Pearson sought to produce a flag which embodied history and tradition, but he also wanted to excise the Union Jack as a reminder of Canada's heritage and links to the [[United Kingdom]]. Hence, the issue was not whether the maple leaf was pre-eminently Canadian, but rather whether the nation should exclude the British-related component from its identity. === Diefenbaker opposition === Diefenbaker led the opposition to the Maple Leaf flag, arguing for the retention of the Canadian Red Ensign. Diefenbaker and his lieutenants mounted a [[filibuster]]. The seemingly endless debate raged on in Parliament and the press with no side giving quarter. Pearson forced members of Parliament to stay over the summer, but that did not help. On September 10, 1964, the Prime Minister yielded to the suggestion that the matter be referred to a special flag committee. The key member of the 15-person panel, Liberal Member of Parliament [[John Matheson]] said that they "were asked to produce a flag for Canada and in six weeks!" == Special flag committee == [[File:Canada flag Group C Finalist.svg|thumb|200px|"Group C" finalist considered by Parliamentary committee]] On September 10, 1964, a committee of 15 Members of Parliament was announced. It was made up of seven [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberals]], five [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|Conservatives]] (PC) and one each from the [[New Democratic Party of Canada|New Democratic Party]] (NDP), the [[Social Credit Party of Canada|Social Credit Party]] and the [[Ralliement créditiste]]. The Committee members were as follows:{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! [[Member of the Canadian House of Commons|MP]] ! [[political parties of Canada|Party]] ! [[Provinces and territories of Canada|Province/Territory]] |- | Chairman [[Herman Maxwell Batten]] | Liberal | Newfoundland |- | [[Léo Cadieux]] | Liberal | Quebec |- | [[Grant Deachman]] | Liberal | British Columbia |- | [[Jean-Eudes Dubé]] | Liberal | New Brunswick |- | [[Hugh John Flemming]] | PC | New Brunswick |- | [[Margaret Konantz]] | Liberal | Manitoba |- | [[Raymond Langlois]] | Ralliement créditiste{{cite web |url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/parlinfo/Files/Parliamentarian.aspx?Item=184bb42b-3d9a-445d-a741-c2acec461ffd&Language=E&Section=ALL |title=LANGLOIS, Raymond, B.A., B.Sc., B.Ed. |author= |publisher=Library of Parliament |accessdate=17 February 2014}} | Quebec |- | [[Marcel Lessard]] | Social Credit | Quebec |- | [[Joseph Macaluso]] | Liberal | Ontario |- | [[John Matheson]] | Liberal | Ontario |- | [[Jay Monteith]] | PC | Ontario |- | [[David Vaughan Pugh]] | PC | British Columbia |- | [[Reynold Rapp]] | PC | Saskatchewan |- | [[Théogène Ricard]] | PC | Quebec |- | [[Reid Scott]] | NDP | Ontario |} The Conservatives at first saw this event as a victory, for they knew that all previous flag committees had suffered miscarriages. During the next six weeks the committee held 35 lengthy meetings. Thousands of suggestions also poured in from a public engaged in what had become a great Canadian debate about identity and how best to represent it. 3,541 entries were submitted: many contained common elements: * 2,136 contained [[maple]] leaves * 408 contained Union Jacks * 389 contained [[beaver]]s * 359 contained [[Fleurs-de-lys]] At the last minute, Matheson slipped a flag designed by historian [[George Stanley]] into the mix. The idea came to him while standing in front of the Mackenzie Building of the [[Royal Military College of Canada]], while viewing the college flag flying in the wind. Stanley submitted a March 23, 1964 [[George Stanley#Designer of the Canadian Flag|formal detailed memorandum]]{{Cite web |url=http://people.stfx.ca/lstanley/stanley/flagmemo2.htm |title=Full text of George Stanley's Flag Memorandum |access-date=March 19, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140309045945/http://people.stfx.ca/lstanley/stanley/flagmemo2.htm |archive-date=March 9, 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} to John Matheson on the history of Canada's emblems, predating Pearson's raising the issue, in which he warned that any new flag "must avoid the use of national or racial symbols that are of a divisive nature" and that it would be "clearly inadvisable" to create a flag that carried either a Union Jack or a Fleur-de-lis. The design put forward had a single red maple leaf on a white plain background, flanked by two red borders, based on the design of the flag of the Royal Military College. The voting was held on October 22, 1964, when the committee’s final contest pitted Pearson’s pennant against Stanley’s. Assuming that the Liberals would vote for the Prime Minister’s design, the Conservatives backed Stanley. They were outmaneuvered by the Liberals who had agreed with others to choose the Stanley Maple Leaf flag. The Liberals voted for the red and white flag, making the selection unanimous (15–0).{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/insight/2015/02/13/how-the-vote-on-canadas-flag-was-rigged.html |title=How the vote on Canada's flag was 'rigged' | Toronto Star |publisher=Thestar.com |date=2015-02-13 |accessdate=2016-04-18}} == House of Commons == === Debate === The committee had made its decision, but not the House of Commons. Diefenbaker would not budge, so the debate continued for six weeks as the Conservatives launched a [[filibuster]]. The debate had become so ugly that the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' called it "The Great Flag Farce." === Closure and vote === The debate was prolonged until one of Diefenbaker's own senior members, [[Léon Balcer]], and the Créditiste, [[Réal Caouette]], advised the government to cut off debate by applying [[cloture|closure]]. Pearson did so, and after some 250 speeches, the final vote adopting the Stanley flag took place at 2:15 on the morning of December 15, 1964, with Balcer and the other francophone Conservatives swinging behind the Liberals. The committee's recommendation was accepted 163 to 78. At 2:00 AM, immediately after the successful vote, Matheson wrote to Stanley: "Your proposed flag has just now been approved by the Commons 163 to 78. Congratulations. I believe it is an excellent flag that will serve Canada well."{{Cite web |url=http://people.stfx.ca/lstanley/stanley/postcard.htm |title=John Matheson's postcard to George Stanley, 15 December 1964, 2:00 AM, announcing the House of Commons' approval of Stanley's design for the new Canadian Flag |access-date=March 19, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303232416/http://people.stfx.ca/lstanley/stanley/postcard.htm |archive-date=March 3, 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} On the afternoon of December 15, the Commons also voted in favor of continued use of the Union Flag as a symbol of Canada's allegiance to the Crown and its membership in the [[Commonwealth of Nations]]. Senate approval followed on December 17, 1964. The "Royal Union Flag", as it would be officially termed, would be put alongside the new flag on days of Commonwealth significance. == Aftermath == Queen [[Elizabeth II]] approved the Maple Leaf flag by signing a royal proclamation on January 28, 1965, when both Prime Minister Pearson and Leader of the Opposition Diefenbaker were in London attending the funeral of Sir [[Winston Churchill]]. The flag was inaugurated on February 15, 1965, at an official ceremony held on [[Parliament Hill]] in [[Ottawa]] in the presence of [[Governor General of Canada|Governor General]] Major-General [[Georges Vanier]], the prime minister, the members of the Cabinet, and Canadian parliamentarians. Also throughout Canada, at the [[United Nations]] in [[New York City]], and at Canadian legations and on Canadian ships throughout the world, the Canadian Red Ensign was lowered and the Maple Leaf flag was raised. As journalist [[George Bain (journalist)|George Bain]] wrote of the occasion, the flag "looked bold and clean, and distinctively our own."{{cite web |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/the-flag-distinctively-our-own-feature/ |title=The Flag: Distinctively Our Own |last=Hillmer |first=Norman |author-link=Norman Hillmer |date=14 February 2012 |website=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]] |accessdate=17 February 2014}} Attachment to the old Canadian Red Ensign has persisted among many people, especially veterans.https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-symbolism-of-an-individual-flying-the-Red-Ensign-instead-of-the-modern-Canadian-flag In 1967, the Canadian Government first used the Canadian Coat of Arms (whose shield was used on the Red Ensign) on a red flag for [[Canadian Centennial|the nation's centennial celebrations]].{{cite web |url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/ca_coa.html |title=Canadian Coat-of-Arms flag |last=Borsa |first=Bill |date=20 February 2004 |website=[[Flags of the World]] |accessdate=17 February 2014}} It was designed to appeal to those who were used to the Red Ensign and had not yet become accustomed to the Maple Leaf Flag. === Provincial flags === {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = | image1 = Flag of Manitoba.svg | alt1 = | image2 = Flag of Ontario.svg | alt2 = | footer = After the debate, Manitoba and Ontario adopted versions of the Red Ensign as basis for their provincial flags. }} The Canadian Red Ensign itself can sometimes be seen today in Canada, often in connection to veterans' associations.{{cite web |url=http://www.legion.ca/who-we-are/ritual-and-awards/colour-party/ |title=Royal Canadian Legion - Colour Party|date=25 February 2016 |website=[[Royal Canadian Legion]] |accessdate=25 February 2016}} In addition, the provinces of [[Manitoba]] and [[Ontario]] adopted their own versions of the Red Ensign as their respective provincial flags in the wake of the national flag debate. On the other hand, [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]] used the Union Flag as [[Flag of Newfoundland and Labrador|its provincial flag]] from 1952 until 1980; the blue triangles on the new flag adopted in 1980 are meant as a tribute to the Union Flag.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.nl.ca/aboutnl/flag.html |title=Provincial Flag |author= |publisher=[[Government of Newfoundland and Labrador]] |accessdate=16 February 2014}} [[British Columbia]]'s [[Flag of British Columbia|flag]], which features the Union Flag in its top portion, was introduced in 1960 and is actually based on the shield of the [[Coat of arms of British Columbia|provincial coat of arms]], which dates back to 1906.{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.bc.ca/bcfacts/ |title=B.C. Quick Facts |author= |publisher=[[British Columbia|Province of British Columbia]] |accessdate=17 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140216065524/http://www.gov.bc.ca/bcfacts/ |archivedate=16 February 2014 |df= }} Hence, both Newfoundland's use of the Union Flag and the adoption of BC's flag are unrelated to (and, in fact, pre-date) the great flag debate. === National Flag Day === Since 1996, February 15 has been commemorated as [[National Flag of Canada Day]] in Canada. == See also == {{Portal|History of Canada}} * [[History of Canada]] * [[Australian flag debate]] * [[New Zealand flag debate]] * [[Northern Ireland flags issue]] * [[Flag of Manitoba]] * [[Flag of Ontario]] == Notes == {{reflist}} == Bibliography == * Albinski, H.S. Stanley's Flag Memorandum, 23 March 1964] == External links == * [http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/politics/language-culture/the-great-canadian-flag-debate/topic-the-great-canadian-flag-debate.html CBC Digital Archives—The Great Canadian Flag Debate] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050524142911/http://personal.nbnet.nb.ca/ensign/replacing.html Story of the Red Ensign] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070323114219/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20070320.wxflag20/BNStory/National/ Great Flag Debate continues over Vimy Ridge anniversary] [[Category:Canadian culture]] [[Category:Flags of Canada]] [[Category:Political history of Canada]] [[Category:1964 in Canada]] [[Category:History of Canada (1960–81)]] [[Category:Flag controversies]] [[Category:John Diefenbaker]] [[Category:Political controversies in Canada]] [[Category:1963 in Canada]] [[Category:Political debates]] [[Category:1963 in Canadian politics]] [[Category:1964 in Canadian politics]]
