| map_image = File:Mexico general election 2018.svg | map_size = 350px | map_caption = States won by López Obrador in red, Anaya in blue. | title = President | before_election = [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] | before_party = Institutional Revolutionary Party | after_party = National Regeneration Movement | after_election = [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador]] }} {{Politics of Mexico}}
'''General elections''' were held in [[Mexico]] on 1 July 2018.<ref>[http://www.senado.gob.mx/consultoria/calendario-electoral.php Electoral Calendar] Senate of the Republic (in Spanish)</ref> Voters elected a new [[President of Mexico]] to serve a term of five years and ten months (reduced by two months from the constitutional mandate due to a change in the inauguration date as of 2014),<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/23-04-2018/3410806 |title=Más allá del debate: corrupción y violencia sin control marcan agenda en la elección mexicana |author=Redacción| date=23 April 2018 |publisher=Sin Embargo |access-date=1 July 2018 |quote="Seis candidatos a la carrera para ocupar Los Pinos a partir del próximo primero de diciembre por un período de cinco años y 10 meses. (A partir de la Reforma Electora de 2014, el Presidente de los Estados Unidos Mexicanos tomará posesión el 1 de octubre de cada año empezando en 2024 por un período de seis años.)"}}</ref> 128 members of the [[Senate of the Republic (Mexico)|Senate]] for a period of six years and 500 members of the [[Chamber of Deputies (Mexico)|Chamber of Deputies]] for a period of three years. It was one of the largest election days in Mexican history, with most of the nation's states holding state and local elections on the same day, including nine governorships, with over 3,400 positions subject to elections at all levels of government.<ref name = "ABC-Sveen-2018-07-02" /> It was the most violent campaign Mexico has experienced in recent history, with 130 political figures killed since September 2017.<ref name = "ABC-Sveen-2018-07-02" />
The incumbent president [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] was not [[Sexenio (Mexico)|constitutionally]] eligible for a second term. Incumbent members of the legislature are term-limited, thus all members of Congress will be newly elected. As a consequence of the political reform of 2014, the members of the legislature elected in this election will be the first allowed to run for reelection in subsequent elections. The [[National Electoral Institute]] (INE) officially declared the new process underway on 8 September 2017.
The presidential election was won by [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador]] of the [[National Regeneration Movement]] (MORENA), running as the candidate of the ''[[Juntos Haremos Historia]]'' alliance.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mexico election: López Obrador vows profound change after win |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-44677829 |accessdate=2 July 2018 |agency=BBC News |date=2 July 2018}}</ref> This is the first time a candidate won an outright majority (according to official vote counts) since [[Mexican general election, 1988|1988]],<ref name="ReutersMurray">{{cite web|title=Mexican Lopez Obrador wins historic election landslide for left|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mexico-election/mexican-lopez-obrador-wins-historic-election-landslide-for-left-idUSKBN1JR15F|agency=Reuters|first=Christine|last=Murray|first2=Diego|last2=Oré|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> and the first time that a candidate not from the [[Institutional Revolutionary Party]] (PRI) or its predecessors has done so since the [[Mexican Revolution]]. This election also marked both the worst electoral defeat suffered by the PRI and the worst electoral defeat for a sitting Mexican government since [[universal suffrage]] was adopted in the country in 1917.{{efn|Universal male suffrage was adopted in 1917, while women acquired the right to vote in Federal elections in 1953.}}
==Electoral system== The country's president is elected by [[Plurality (voting)|plurality]] in a single round of voting.<ref>[http://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/2246/ Election Guide - Mexico] IFES</ref>
The 500 members of the Chamber of Deputies are elected to three-year terms by two methods; 300 are elected in single-member constituencies by [[first-past-the-post voting]], with the remaining 200 elected from five regional constituencies by [[proportional representation]], with seats allocated using the simple quotient and [[largest remainder method]]. No party is allowed to hold more than 300 seats.<ref>[http://www.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/2211_B.htm Electoral system] IPU</ref> Members may hold office for up to four consecutive terms.<ref name = "Term Limits-Agren-USAToday-2014">{{ cite news |url= https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2014/01/31/mexico-election-reform/5086989/ |work=USA Today |title= Mexico ends decades-long ban on re-election |author=David Agren |date=31 January 2014 |accessdate=31 January 2014 }} </ref>
The 128 members of the Senate are elected to six-year terms, concurrent with the president, and also elected by two methods, with 96 elected in 32 three-member constituencies based on the [[States of Mexico|states]] and 32 elected in a single nationwide constituency by [[proportional representation]]. In the three-member constituencies, two winning candidates shall be allocated to the party receiving the highest number of votes and one seat to the party receiving the second-highest number of votes.<ref>[http://www.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/2212_B.htm Electoral system] Mexican Legislative Election Process IPU</ref> Members may hold office for up to two terms.<ref name = "Term Limits-Agren-USAToday-2014" />
==Presidential candidates==
===''Por México al Frente''=== {{Main Article|Por México al Frente}}(English: "For Mexico to the Front") The center-right [[National Action Party (Mexico)|National Action Party]] and the center-left [[Party of the Democratic Revolution]] and [[Citizens' Movement (Mexico)|Citizens' Movement]] – which both nominated [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador]] in the elections of 2006 and 2012 – formed an alliance for the election, in an effort to defeat both the ruling party, the [[Institutional Revolutionary Party|PRI]], and the front-runner Andrés Manuel López Obrador of the [[National Regeneration Movement]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title=PAN, PRD y MC avalan Frente pero sin definir sus alcances|url=https://politico.mx/central-electoral/elecciones-2018/pan-avala-frente-opositor-con-el-prd-para-2018/|access-date=5 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.diariocambio.com.mx/2017/nacional/item/19923-se-confirma-el-frente-opositor-pan-mc-y-prd-iran-en-alianza-para-2018 |title=Se confirma el Frente Opositor: PAN, MC y PRD irán en alianza para 2018|access-date=5 September 2017|website=DiarioCambio.com.mx|language=es-es}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=El PAN, el PRD y Movimiento Ciudadano constituirán un frente común para 2018|url=http://expansion.mx/politica/2017/09/04/el-pan-el-prd-y-movimiento-ciudadano-constituiran-un-frente-comun-para-2018 |accessdate=5 September 2017|work=Expansión|language=es-MX}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite news|title=Registran Frente Amplio ante el INE |url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/nacion/politica/registran-frente-amplio-ante-el-ine|date=5 September 2017 |accessdate=5 September 2017|work=El Universal|language=es}} </ref><ref name="reforma.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.reforma.com/aplicacioneslibre/preacceso/articulo/default.aspx?id=1202357&urlredirect=http://www.reforma.com/aplicaciones/articulo/default.aspx?id=1202357 |title=Formalizan PAN, PRD y MC Frente ante INE |access-date=5 September 2017|website=www.reforma.com}}</ref><ref name=":0"/>
On 5 September, the electoral alliance was officially registered with the INE as ''Frente Ciudadano por México'' (Citizen Front for Mexico).<ref name="reforma.com"/> On 8 December the coalition changed its name to ''Por México al Frente'' (Mexico to the Front). The next day, [[Ricardo Anaya Cortés]], president of the PAN, resigned from his position and expressed his intent to be the alliance's candidate.<ref>{{cite web |last = |first = |title =Anaya renunció al PAN, va por candidatura del Frente |url =https://politico.mx/central-electoral/elecciones-2018/presidencial/anaya-renuncia-al-pan-va-por-candidatura-del-frente/ |publisher =Político MX |date =9 September 2017 |access-date =9 December 2017|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= 'Todos por México' será el nombre de coalición de Meade|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/2018/01/15/1213855|date=15 January 2018|accessdate=15 January 2018|work=Excelsior|language=es-ES}}</ref>
The former first lady [[Margarita Zavala]] submitted her resignation from the PAN on 6 October, after being a member for 33 years, and registered as an independent candidate six days later.<ref>{{cite web |last = |first = |title =Zavala renuncia al PAN, buscará candidatura independiente | url =https://politico.mx/central-electoral/elecciones-2018/margarita-zavala-emitir%C3%A1-pronunciamiento-sobre-su-candidatura/ | publisher =Político MX |date=6 October 2017 |access-date =11 December 2017|language=es}}</ref> She sought the presidency through an independent bid, but withdrew on 16 May 2018.
'''Nominee'''
* [[Ricardo Anaya Cortés]], former president of the National Action Party.
===''Todos por México''=== {{Main|Todos por México}}(English: "Everyone for Mexico") The coalition is composed of the [[Institutional Revolutionary Party]], the [[Ecologist Green Party of Mexico]], and the [[New Alliance Party (Mexico)|PANAL]]. On 9 August 2017, the PRI revised its requirements for presidential candidates, eliminating the requirement that candidates must have 10 years of party membership, and allowing non-party members to lead the party.<ref name="reform">{{cite news|last=Stargardter|first=Gabriel|title=Mexico ruling party's reform strengthens president ahead of 2018 vote|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mexico-politics-analysis/mexico-ruling-partys-reform-strengthens-president-ahead-of-2018-vote-idUSKBN1AR04T|date=10 August 2017|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref>
This move benefited finance secretary [[José Antonio Meade Kuribreña]], who is not a member of the PRI,<ref> {{cite news|last=Webber|first=Jude|title=Mexico's embattled PRI replaces leader ahead of July election|url=https://www.ft.com/content/85359ace-4e7b-11e8-a7a9-37318e776bab|website=[[Financial Times]]|date=2 May 2018}}</ref> as well as education secretary [[Aurelio Nuño Mayer]], whose length of membership was questioned.<ref name="reform"/> Meade was considered the favorite, because while the PRI was dogged by scandal and controversy, Meade was personally unaffected.<ref>{{cite news|last=Villegas|first=Paulina|title=Mexico’s Finance Minister Says He’ll Run for President|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/27/world/americas/jose-antonio-meade-mexico.html| work = New York Times |date=27 November 2017}}</ref>
On 27 November, Meade resigned from cabinet and announced his intention to be the PRI's candidate in the upcoming election.<ref>{{cite news |last=Stevenson |first=Mark |title=Mexico Treasury Secretary announces presidential bid |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sns-bc-lt--mexico-politics-20171127-story.html |website=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=8 June 2018 |date=27 November 2017}}</ref> He quickly received the support of President Peña Nieto and PRI-linked institutions such as the CTM union.<ref>{{cite news |last=Agren |first=David |title=Mexico is a democracy, but the ghosts of one-party rule live on |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/11/27/mexico-is-a-democracy-but-the-ghosts-of-one-party-rule-live-on/?noredirect=on |date=27 November 2017}}</ref> With no challengers, Meade became the presumptive nominee.<ref>{{cite web|last=Miranda|first=Kevin|title=José Antonio Meade, oficial precandidato del PRI para 2018|url=https://www.debate.com.mx/politica/Jose-Antonio-Meade-oficial-precandidato-del-PRI-para-2018-20171203-0047.html|website=El Debate|date=3 December 2018}}</ref> On 18 February 2018, the PRI held its convention of delegates, where Meade was formally selected as the party's presidential candidate.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mexico Picks its Presidential Candidates, AMLO in the Lead |url=https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Mexico-Picks-its-Presidential-Candidates-AMLO-in-the-Lead-20180218-0018.html|website=Telesur|date=18 February 2018}}</ref> Meade is the PRI's first presidential candidate in its almost 90-year history not to be a member of the party.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mexico's presidential campaign takes shape, with 3 candidates formally accepting party nominations |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-mexico-candidates-20180218-story.html |agency=Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=¿Quién es José Antonio Meade? El candidato independiente del PRI|url=http://www.milenio.com/elecciones-mexico-2018/jose-antonio-meade-candidato-independiente-pri|work=Milenio|accessdate=29 June 2018}}</ref>
Due to the circumstances of Meade's candidacy, critics compared his selection to the PRI's historical practice of ''dedazo'' ("tap of the finger"), where presidents hand-picked their successor.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2017/11/30/jose-antonio-meade-is-the-pris-candidate-for-mexicos-presidency |title= José Antonio Meade is the PRI’s candidate for Mexico’s presidency |work= [[The Economist]] |date= 30 November 2017 |accessdate= 7 June 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Ramos |first=Jorge |url= https://splinternews.com/el-dedazo-makes-a-comeback-in-mexico-1821012490 |title= ‘El Dedazo’ Makes a Comeback in Mexico |work= Splinter |date= 5 December 2017 |accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref>
The coalition was initially named ''Meade Ciudadano por México'' (English: Citizen Meade for Mexico), until the INE deemed it unconstitutional to include a candidate's name within the coalition's name, on the grounds that the presidential candidate would receive advertising from every piece of campaign advertising of the coalition used for local candidates. The coalition subsequently changed its name to ''Todos por México'' (Everyone for Mexico).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elfinanciero.com.mx/nacional/avanza-en-ine-reves-al-nombre-de-coalicion-de-meade.html|title=INE perfila quitar el nombre de Meade a la coalición del PRI|website=www.elfinanciero.com.mx|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
'''Nominee'''
* [[José Antonio Meade Kuribreña]], former [[Secretary of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)|Secretary of Foreign Affairs]], [[Secretariat of Social Development (Mexico)|Secretary of Social Development]], and [[Secretary of Finance and Public Credit]] during the Peña Nieto administration; Secretary of Finance and Public Credit and [[Secretariat of Energy (Mexico)|Secretary of Energy]] during the [[Felipe Calderón]] administration.
===''Juntos Haremos Historia''=== {{Main Article|Juntos Haremos Historia}}(English: "Together We Will Make History") The coalition is composed of the [[National Regeneration Movement]] (MORENA), the [[Labor Party (Mexico)|Labor Party]], and the [[Social Encounter Party]].<ref> {{cite news|title=Aprueba PT coalición con Morena en elecciones de 2018|url=https://www.sdpnoticias.com/nacional/2017/06/25/aprueba-pt-coalicion-con-morena-en-elecciones-de-2018|date=25 June 2017|accessdate=5 September 2017|work=SDPnoticias.com|language=es-ES}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=PES irá en alianza con Morena para presidencial de 2018|url=https://www.sdpnoticias.com/nacional/2017/11/26/pes-ira-en-alianza-con-morena-para-presidencial-de-2018|date=26 November 2017|accessdate=27 November 2017|work=SDPnoticias.com|language=es-ES}} </ref>
On 12 December [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador]] registered as the presumptive nominee for MORENA and submitted his resignation as party president. This is López Obrador's third presidential bid; the previous two attempts were with the [[Party of the Democratic Revolution|PRD]]. After the 2012 presidential election, López Obrador left the PRD to found MORENA. This is MORENA's first presidential election. Joining MORENA in the ''Juntos Haremos Historia'' coalition is the left-wing Labor Party and the right-wing Social Encounter Party.<ref> {{cite web |last = |first = |title =López Obrador registra precandidatura y anuncia proyecto de nación |url =http://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/2017/12/13/1207316 |publisher =Excelsior |date=13 December 2017 |access-date =16 January 2018|language=es}}</ref>
'''Nominee'''
* [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador]], former Head of Government of Mexico City, 2006 and 2012 presidential candidate.
===Independents=== [[File:BRONCO.svg|thumb|Logo for Rodríguez's campaign|200px]] For the first time in Mexico's modern democratic history, candidates were allowed to run for the presidency as independents.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2017/10/26/independents-stampede-into-mexicos-presidential-election|date=26 October 2017|title=Independents stampede into Mexico’s presidential election|work=The Economist|accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref> Several people announced their intention to contest the election as an independent candidate.
[[Margarita Zavala]], a lawyer, former deputy and wife of former president [[Felipe Calderón]], had originally intended to run as the PAN nominee; however, on 6 October, she left the party and launched an independent bid. Explaining her decision, she said that the formation of ''Por México al Frente'' meant there would be no internal PAN selection, denying her a chance to be a candidate.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mexico-politics/mexico-ex-first-lady-leaves-opposition-party-for-presidency-bid-idUSKBN1CB2W3|first=Dave|last=Graham|date=6 October 2017|title=Mexico ex-first lady leaves opposition party for presidency bid|agency=Reuters|accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref> [[Jaime Rodríguez Calderón]], the independent governor of [[Nuevo León]], also announced his candidacy,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/10/19/el-bronco-mexicos-most-successful-independent-sets-sights-on-2018-presidency.html|first=Jan-Albert|last=Hootsen|date=16 October 2016|title='El Bronco,' Mexico’s most successful independent, sets sight on 2018 presidency|work=Fox News|accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref> as did Senator [[Armando Ríos Piter]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.eleconomista.com.mx/politica/Voy-independiente-pero-no-solo-Rios-Piter-20170521-0061.html|first=Diego|last=Badillo|date=21 May 2017|title=Voy independiente pero no solo: Ríos Piter|work=El Economista|accessdate=8 February 2018 |deadurl=no| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180209063719/https://www.eleconomista.com.mx/politica/Voy-independiente-pero-no-solo-Rios-Piter-20170521-0061.html| archivedate=9 February 2018}}</ref>
The [[National Indigenous Congress]] announced on 28 May 2017 the election of [[María de Jesús Patricio Martínez]] as their spokeswoman and indigenous representative for the 2018 general election, aiming to obtain an independent candidacy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/es/2017/05/28/los-pueblos-indigenas-de-mexico-eligen-a-su-vocera-e-irrumpen-en-el-escenario-politico/|title=Los pueblos indígenas de México eligen a su vocera e irrumpen en el escenario político (The indigenous peoples of Mexico elect their spokesperson and break into the political scene)|last=Concheiro|first=Luciano|date=28 May 2017|work=The New York Times| access-date=1 June 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language= English |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Only Zavala gathered enough signatures to appear on the ballot;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/elecciones-2018/el-bronco-y-rios-piter-fuera-de-la-boleta-electoral|title=“El Bronco” y Ríos Piter, fuera de la boleta electoral|date=16 March 2018|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> however, on 10 April the Electoral Court accepted an appeal from Rodríguez and ordered the National Electoral Institute to register him as candidate.<ref> {{cite web |url=https://elpais.com/internacional/2018/04/10/actualidad/1523349178_499043.html |title=El Tribunal Electoral mete a El Bronco en la carrera presidencial con una polémica decisión |work=El País |date=10 April 2018 |language=Spanish |accessdate=10 April 2018}}</ref>
On 16 May Zavala announced she was withdrawing her candidacy.<ref> {{cite web |url=https://expansion.mx/nacional/2018/05/16/margarita-zavala-renuncia-a-su-candidatura |title=Margarita Zavala renuncia a su candidatura presidencial |work=Expansión |date=16 May 2018 |language=Spanish |accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref>
==Opinion polls== {{main|Opinion polling for the Mexican general election, 2018}} [[File:Tendencia histórica de la intención de voto.png|thumb|center|750px|Historical trend of voting intentions for the candidates for the Mexican presidency in 2018.]]
==Campaigns== ===Timeline===
====January==== As in the [[Mexican general election, 2006|2006]] and [[Mexican general election, 2012|2012]] federal elections, the 2018 campaign featured numerous accusations and [[attack ad]]vertisements directed at the leftist frontrunner candidate [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador]], who contested the elections with the support of his party [[National Regeneration Movement|MORENA]]. A [[Red Scare]]-like campaign was used by the PRI and PAN candidates to convince voters that a López Obrador victory would turn Mexico into "another Venezuela".<ref> {{Cite news|url=https://www.periodismonegro.mx/2018/01/19/la-campana-del-miedo-contra-amlo/|work=Periodismo Negro|date=19 January 2018|title=La campaña del miedo contra López Obrador|language=Spanish|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.yucatan.com.mx/editorial/las-campanas-del-miedo|work=Diario de Yucatán|date=11 January 2018|title=Las Campañas del miedo|language=Spanish|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref>
In a speech, PRI president {{ill|Enrique Ochoa Reza|es}} said that "if the people from MORENA like Venezuela so much, they should just go and live there".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elfinanciero.com.mx/nacional/si-a-los-de-morena-les-gusta-venezuela-que-se-vayan-a-vivir-alla-ochoa.html|work=Periodismo Negro|date=15 November 2017|title=Si a los de Morena les gusta Venezuela, que se vayan a vivir allá: Ochoa|language=Spanish|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref> The PRI was believed to have hired [[Venezuela]]n [[right-wing]] political strategist [[JJ Rendón]] to work in their campaign, as he stated in January that he would do "everything within the law to prevent López Obrador from becoming President"; Rendón had previously worked for the PRI during [[Enrique Peña Nieto|Peña Nieto's]] 2012 presidential campaign.<ref name="Aristegui Noticias">{{Cite news|url=https://aristeguinoticias.com/1401/mexico/pri-se-desmarca-del-publicista-jj-rendon-amlo-pide-evitar-violencia-politica/|work=Aristegui Noticias|date=14 January 2018|title=PRI se desmarca del publicista JJ Rendón; López Obrador pide evitar violencia política|language=Spanish|accessdate=14 January 2018}}</ref>
In January, former president [[Felipe Calderón]] shared a video on via social media, in which a Venezuelan citizen living in Mexico warned voters not to vote for López Obrador, as he would put Mexico in the "path to ruin" like [[Chavismo]] had done in her country. It later surfaced that the woman, whose name is Carmen Martilez, is an actress who previously had uploaded a video in which she asked for street vendors to be "exterminated".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/19-01-2018/3375593|work=Sin Embargo|date=19 January 2018|title="Venezolana" que llora y pide no votar por López Obrador, también quiere exterminar vendedores en CdMx|language=Spanish|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref>
That same month, the PRI began to claim that López Obrador's campaign was supported by "Venezuelan and Russian interests". López Obrador dismissed the accusations and later joked about them, calling himself "Andrés Manuelovich".<ref name="reuters.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mexico-politics/andres-manuelovich-mexican-leftist-laughs-off-russia-election-jabs-idUSKBN1F735X|title='Andres Manuelovich': Mexican leftist laughs off Russia election jabs|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|agency=Reuters|accessdate=9 April 2018}} </ref><ref name="aristeguinoticias.com">{{cite web|url=https://aristeguinoticias.com/tag/andres-manuel-lopez-obrador/|title=PRI estrena spot sobre “miedo” al “Peje” (Video)|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
Later in January, citizens across the country received phone calls originating in the city of [[Puebla City|Puebla]], in which a recorded message warned them not to vote for López Obrador because he supposedly agreed to sell Mexico's oil to "the Russians". The [[Movimiento de Regeneración Nacional|MORENA]] representative in Puebla asked for an investigation into the phone calls.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/520563/arman-campana-contra-amlo-en-puebla-los-rusos-vienen-quitarnos-nuestro-petroleo-dicen-en-llamadas|work=Proceso|date=31 January 2018|title=Arman campaña contra López Obrador en Puebla; "los rusos vienen a quitarnos nuestro petróleo", dicen en llamadas|language=Spanish|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.elsoldepuebla.com.mx/local/pediran-que-se-investiguen-llamadas-telefonicas-contra-amlo|work=El Sol de Puebla|date=31 January 2018|title=Pedirán que se investiguen llamadas telefónicas contra López Obrador|language=Spanish|accessdate=31 January 2018}} </ref> In March, telephone company [[Axtel]] traced the number that made the calls, revealing it was a number that the government of Puebla (whose governor is from the PAN) controlled. Puebla's government denied the accusations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://aristeguinoticias.com/1303/mexico/gobierno-de-puebla-contrato-linea-telefonica-desde-donde-se-ataco-a-amlo-contrato-ya-vencio-responde/|title=Gobierno de Puebla contrató línea telefónica desde donde se atacó a López Obrador; contrato ya venció, responde - Aristegui Noticias|website=aristeguinoticias.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}} </ref> Also in January, López Obrador uploaded a video via social media asking president Peña Nieto and PRI president Ochoa Reza to "calm down", and advised them to take some "[[Amlodipine|López Obradordipine]]".<ref> {{Cite news|url=https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/amlodipino-is-for-whatever-ails-epn/|work=Mexico News Daily|date=18 January 2018|title=Amlodipino is for whatever ails Peña Nieto|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref>
A [[jingle]] entitled ''Movimiento Naranja'', which was recorded for the political party [[Movimiento Ciudadano|''Movimiento Ciudadano'']] (which is part of the ''Por México al Frente'' coalition, along with the PAN and the PRD) and performed by an [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous]] child called Yuawi, became [[Viral video|viral]] and Yuawi turned into a celebrity overnight.<ref> {{Cite news|url=http://www.semana.com/mundo/articulo/movimiento-naranja-cancion-viral-en-redes-sociales/553318|work=Semana|date=20 January 2018|title=Movimiento Naranja, la propaganda política que suena hasta en las discotecas|language=Spanish|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref><ref> {{Cite news|url=http://www.europafm.com/programas/we-sound-radio/noticias/viral/movimiento-naranja-pegadiza-cancion-campana-politica-que-suena-todas-partes_201801225a65a8240cf29cc180756dfa.html|work=Europa FM|date=22 January 2018|title='Movimiento Naranja’ la pegadiza canción de una campaña política que suena en todas partes|language=Spanish|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref> Drawing on its success, the pre-candidate for the Frente, [[Ricardo Anaya Cortés|Ricardo Anaya]] recorded a video in which he performed the song with Yuawi.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.milenio.com/elecciones-mexico-2018/yuawi-ricardo-anaya-presidente-pan-por-mexico-al-frente-movimiento-ciudadano_0_1108689458.html|work=Milenio|date=23 January 2018|title=Yuawi y Anaya se avientan un "palomazo"|language=Spanish|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref>
PRI candidate [[José Antonio Meade Kuribreña|José Antonio Meade]] was accused of [[plagiarism]] when it was noted that one of his ads, in which he criticized a "populist" speech on TV, was identical to an ad that was used by [[Justin Trudeau]] when he became leader of the [[Liberal Party of Canada]] in 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sdpnoticias.com/nacional/2018/01/18/destacan-parecido-estilo-en-spot-de-meade-a-uno-de-trudeau|work=SDP Noticias|date=18 January 2018|title=Destacan parecido estilo en spot de Meade a uno de Trudeau|language=Spanish|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref>
====February==== Later in February, the PRI's [[Enrique Ochoa Reza]] tweeted that PRI politicians who defected to MORENA as ''Prietos que no aprietan'' (Dark-skinned people who can't get a hold) while trying to make a pun on the word PRI-etos (because ''morena'' is a synonym for ''prieto''). The expression was criticized, and Ochoa Reza quickly deleted the tweet as it was interpreted to be racist.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://regeneracion.mx/otra-de-ochoa-reza-llama-prietos-a-seguidores-de-amlo-lo-acusan-de-racista/|title=Otra de Ochoa Reza: llama 'prietos' a seguidores de López Obrador; lo acusan de racista|date=10 February 2018|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
''Aristegui Noticias'' published that Ochoa Reza apologized, and also criticized the insensitive expression, additionally commenting that the part ''que ya no aprietan'' (who cannot hold) could also be interpreted as misogynistic due to being a [[double entendre]] referring to women in relation to the number of sexual relations they have had in their lifetime. Ochoa Reza's tweet apologized to dark-skinned people but not to women.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://aristeguinoticias.com/1102/mexico/ochoa-reza-arremete-contra-prietos-que-dejan-el-pri-lo-llaman-racista-y-se-disculpa/|title=Ochoa Reza arremete contra "prietos" que dejan el PRI; lo tachan de racista y se disculpa - Aristegui Noticias|website=aristeguinoticias.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> Later ''Sinembargo.mx'' revealed that José Antonio Meade justified Enrique Ochoa's usage of the expression, by saying: ''uno se excede y es natural'' (English: one gets-ahead-of-themselves and it is natural) and saying that his quick apology talked positively about him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/12-02-2018/3384628|title=Meade justifica a Ochoa Reza: el comentario fue “un exceso”, dice, pero “uno se excede y es natural”|publisher=}}</ref>
====March==== In March, the [[Attorney General of Mexico|Attorney General of the Republic]] (PGR) started an official investigation into money-laundering allegations against Ricardo Anaya. During the investigation, Santiago Nieto, the ex-chief of FEPADE (the prosecutor's office that focuses on electoral violations) was controversially removed from his job in October 2017, coincidentally right after starting an investigation regarding illicit campaign money from the 2012 presidential campaign that allegedly was received by Peña Nieto and by the future president of [[Pemex]], [[Emilio Lozoya]], from the Brazilian conglomerate [[Odebrecht]]. The ex-chief of FEPADE said that the accusations against Anaya were minor in comparison to Odebretch and Peña Nieto scandal, adding also the same opinion about the money lost by [[Secretariat of Social Development]], to corrupt governors from the PRI such as [[Javier Duarte]], all while José Antonio Meade was the man in charge of the Secretariat of Social Development. The scandal is known as ''La Estafa Maestra'' (The Master Robbery), and about 435 million pesos were lost.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.animalpolitico.com/2018/01/robles-meade-estafa-maestra-sedesol/|title=Con Robles y Meade hubo desvíos al estilo Estafa Maestra por 540 mdp en Sedesol, revela Auditoría|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> The same week the PRI legislators were criticized for voting for stopping the investigation of Odebretch against the wishes of Mexican people and organizations campaigning against corruption such as ''Mexicanos contra la corrupción'' (Mexicans against corruption).<ref> {{cite web|url=https://elpais.com/internacional/2018/03/07/actualidad/1520390316_791182.html|title=El PRI bloquea en el Congreso una investigación del ‘caso Odebrecht’|first=D. M.|last=Pérez|date=8 March 2018|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2018|via=elpais.com}}</ref> The investigation about Odebretch against the [[Pemex]] leader at the time, Lozoya, was legally stopped after a judge controversially ordered it days after.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.culturacolectiva.com/noticias/jueza-suspende-investigacion-contra-lozoya-por-tiempo-indefinido/|title=Caso Odebrecht deja detenidos en todo el mundo, menos en México|date=2 March 2018|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
Santiago Nieto said that the PGR was being used by Peña Nieto's government to tamper with elections and benefit Meade by removing Anaya from the race, complaining that it was a politically motivated use of law-enforcement agencies, which had made more efforts to investigate Anaya in a month than towards investigating Peña Nieto's Odebretch money and Meade's lost Secretariat of Social Development funds over the last six years. Santiago Nieto said the PGR and FEPADE were only attacking the rivals of the PRI, and the investigating organizations were not being neutral.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://aristeguinoticias.com/0203/mexico/por-menos-que-lo-que-ha-hecho-la-pgr-contra-anaya-me-removieron-a-mi-santiago-nieto/|title=Por menos que lo que ha hecho la PGR contra Anaya, me removieron a mí: Santiago Nieto - Aristegui Noticias|website=aristeguinoticias.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
In an interview with ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', Santiago Nieto would later reveal that Peña Nieto's government tried to bribe him to keep him silent, which he refused saying, "Sorry, but I can't receive any money from Peña Nieto." He received menacing phone messages stating: "Death follows you" and "Words of advice: stay out of Trouble", and as a consequence, he feared for the safety of his, and his family's lives.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/ex-mexican-prosecutor-says-he-was-fired-to-stymie-corruption-probe-1521062636|title=Ex-Mexican Prosecutor Says He Was Fired to Stymie Corruption Probe|first=Juan|last=Montes|date=14 March 2018|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2018|website=Wsj.com}}</ref> Additionally as of 2018, it should be noted, that many of the politicians of the PRI political party who supported Peña Nieto during his presidential campaign would be later declared criminals by the Mexican government (some already elected, while others were campaigning concurrently with Peña Nieto, and would be elected),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/2017/04/17/1158092|title=Corrupción envuelve a 11 exgobernadores|date=17 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/19/world/americas/in-mexico-mounting-misdeeds-but-governors-escape-justice.html|title=En México se acumulan los gobernadores corruptos, e impunes|first=Elisabeth|last=Malkin|date=19 April 2017|website=Nytimes.com}}</ref><ref> {{cite web|url=http://regeneracion.mx/conoce-a-los-11-exgobernadores-mas-corruptos-de-mexico/|title=Conoce a los 11 exgobernadores más corruptos de México|date=17 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref> near the end of Peña Nieto's time as president.
A total of 22 state ex-governors, all members from the PRI, were accused of misuse of public funds and misdirection of money (with some money speculated to have been directed to the PRI); only five were sent to jail, with PGR receiving criticism for not investigating further.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/22-04-2017/3196138|title=Son 22 gobernadores del PRI los acusados de desvíos con EPN; el monto en duda: 258 mil millones|first=Dulce|last=Olvera|publisher=}}</ref> Among the most prominent criminals were: [[Tomás Yarrington]] from [[Tamaulipas]] (along his predecessor [[Eugenio Hernández Flores]]), [[Javier Duarte]] from [[Veracruz]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/mexico-americas/la-fg-mexico-duarte-20170717-story.html|title=Former governor of Mexico's Veracruz state extradited from Guatemala to face corruption charges|first=Patrick J.|last=McDonnell|date=17 July 2017|publisher=|via=LA Times}}</ref> [[César Duarte Jáquez]] from [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/mexico/2017/03/30/mexico-ex-gov-flees-texas-evade-corruption-allegations|title=Mexico: Ex-governor flees to Texas to evade corruption allegations | work = Dallas News |date=30 March 2017|publisher=}}</ref> (no family relation between the two Duartes), and [[Roberto Borge]] from [[Quintana Roo]], along their unknown multiple allies who enabled their corruption. Although Peña Nieto was not found to be their ally, by being part of the same political party, there were severely negative consequences to Peña Nieto's image as president, as well as of the PRI.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/articulo/nacion/seguridad/2017/06/5/pgr-e-interpol-capturan-roberto-borge-en-panama|title=PGR e Interpol capturan a Roberto Borge en Panamá|date=5 June 2017|publisher=}}</ref> Also, while not a member of the PRI at the time, Meade's image also received damage, because much of the money was lost while he was in charge of the Secretariat of Social Development, the government ministry that supervises the resources received by each state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/523906/los-desvios-que-meade-no-vio-en-sedesol|title=Los desvíos que Meade no vio en Sedesol - Proceso|date=24 February 2018|website=Proceso.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
Despite the overwhelming evidence against César Duarte, in March 2018 the PGR found him innocent of any crime. The successor governor Javier Corral from the PAN, who previously fought against the [[Televisa|Televisa law]], gave a similar opinion to Santiago Nieto, saying the PGR was being used to protect the allies of Peña Nieto and the PRI, and attack their rivals.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.reforma.com/aplicacioneslibre/articulo/default.aspx?id=1346330&v=5&md5=2f59936ad96e8f39cfeaa31398842aa7&ta=0dfdbac11765226904c16cb9ad1b2efe | title=Perdonan a Duarte; es cinismo.- Corral|website=Reforma.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> López Obrador said that failure to take action against Duarte was one of the main reasons why Mexicans had lost their faith in the PRI, saying the few ex-governors that were declared criminals were only to a pretense of concern.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/526180/por-acciones-como-no-proceder-contra-cesar-duarte-la-gente-ya-no-le-cree-al-pri-amlo|title=Por acciones como no proceder contra César Duarte, la gente ya no le cree al PRI: López Obrador - Proceso|date=14 March 2018|website=Proceso.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
====April and May==== After, Meade decided to change his strategy; and due to his poor reception, Ochoa Reza left his position as president of the PRI on 2 May.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.proceso.com.mx/532502/con-meade-en-la-lona-ochoa-reza-deja-la-presidencia-del-pri-entra-al-relevo-juarez-cisneros|title=Con Meade en la lona, Ochoa Reza deja la presidencia del PRI; entra al relevo Juárez Cisneros - Proceso|date=2 May 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
On 16 May, Margarita Zavala suspended her presidential campaign.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://expansion.mx/nacional/2018/05/16/margarita-zavala-renuncia-a-su-candidatura |title=Margarita Zavala renuncia a su candidatura |language=Spanish |date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=16 May 2018 |newspaper=Expansión}}</ref>
[[Santiago Nieto]] decided to join AMLO's campaign, with both promising to continue the investigation into the alleged scandal involving Peña Nieto, the PRI and Odebretch.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/santiago-nieto-se-suma-a-campana-de-amlo/1240456|title=Santiago Nieto se suma a campaña de AMLO|date=22 May 2018|publisher=}}</ref> Meanwhile, [[César Duarte]] disappeared before being incarcerated, and was subsequently declared a fugitive from justice by the PGR.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/aseguran-4-ranchos-a-cesar-duarte-en-belleza-chihuahua/1241605|title=Aseguran 4 ranchos a César Duarte en Belleza, Chihuahua|date=28 May 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
More than 130 political figures were killed from when the campaign began in September 2017 until July 2018.<ref name = "ABC-Sveen-2018-07-02"> {{cite news | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-07-02/mexico-elections-what-andres-manuel-lopez-obrador-victory-means/9932218 | work = ABC News (Australia) | date = 2 July 2018 | title = Mexico's new president Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador is the result of political upheaval | author = Benjamin Sveen }}</ref>
===Promises and proposals=== López Obrador promised to end many of the benefits received by ex-presidents, particularly the lifelong pension they receive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/2018/03/09/1225293|title=López Obrador se pronuncia por gobierno austero y sin privilegios|date=9 March 2018|website=Excelsior.com.mx|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> He added that he would redirect the money saved to be used to help senior citizens.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/08-01-2018/3371553|title=AMLO dice que en caso de ganar las elecciones eliminará pensiones millonarias a ex presidentes|publisher=}}</ref> Zavala said she would also attempt to end the practice, though she had not decided how to use the money saved, while Meade and Anaya said they would keep the practice going.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/08-04-2018/3405716|title=Margarita Zavala ofrece quitarle la pensión a los ex Presidentes, entre ellos su marido|publisher=}}</ref>
Anaya promised to implement a [[basic income]] for Mexican citizens,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/elecciones-2018/ingreso-basico-universal-principal-propuesta-social-del-frente-pan|title=Ingreso básico universal, principal propuesta social del Frente: PAN|date=26 November 2017|website=Eluniversal.com.mx|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> Anaya said [[Nobel prize]]-winning economist [[Milton Friedman]] supported the idea. While well received, ''[[El Economista (Mexico)|El Economista]]'' criticized how Anaya announced it, and called the idea [[populist]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eleconomista.com.mx/opinion/Desmintiendo-a-Ricardo-Anaya-20171129-0034.html|title=Desmintiendo a Ricardo Anaya|first=Armando Regil|last=Velasco|website=Eleconomista.com.mx|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
Meade proposed to create an office that would track the unique needs of each individual citizen, in what he would call ''Registro Único de Necesidades de Cada Persona'' (Unique Register of the Necessities of Each Person). Citizens on social media mocked the idea as absurd and impossible to develop, comparing it to writing letters to [[Santa Claus]] or just plainly asking for miracles.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://regeneracion.mx/meade-propone-un-registro-nacional-de-necesidades-de-cada-persona-lo-tunden-en-redes/|title=Meade propone un 'Registro Nacional de Necesidades de Cada Persona'; lo tunden en redes|date=18 February 2018|website=Regeneracion.mx|accessdate=9 April 2018}} </ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/rafaelcabrera/meade-prometio-crear-un-registro-nacional-de-necesidades-de|title=Meade prometió crear un "Registro Nacional de Necesidades de Cada Persona" y le están lloviendo peticiones| website=Buzzfeed.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> Meade has supported Peña Nieto's energy reforms, saying that "everyone wins with the ''gasolinazo''", and announcing that if he won he intended to continue it.<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.milenio.com/negocios/gasolinazo-ganan_nuestros_hijos-meade-alzas_combustibles-gasolinas-economia-milenio_0_875312478.html|title=Con 'gasolinazo' ganan nuestros hijos: Meade|first=Silvia|last=Rodríguez|website=Milenio.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> López Obrador promised to end the ''gasolinazos'' by building two new fuel refineries, which would allow more petroleum to be processed into gasoline domestically, thus lowering the price by not outsourcing the refining to other countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.milenio.com/politica/amlo-morena-gasolinas-2018-refinerias-gasolinazo-combustibles-milenio-noticias_0_898110406.html|title=Si triunfa Morena bajarán los costos de la gasolina: López Obrador|website=Milenio.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
Anaya promised to investigate and do everything to make sure President Peña Nieto is sent to jail for his aforementioned multiple presidential scandals, with López Obrador agreeing and suggesting to up the ante by also investigating every living former president.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/2018/03/10/1225497|title=Pide López Obrador a Ricardo Anaya extender denuncia a expresidentes|date=10 March 2018|website=Excelsior.com.mx|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
On 26 January, López Obrador accused the [[International Monetary Fund]] of being an accomplice to corruption in Mexican politics and claimed that its policies are in part responsible for poverty, unemployment, and violence in the country. López Obrador promised that if he won the presidency, Mexico will follow "its own agenda".<ref>{{cite news |title =El FMI es cómplice de la corrupción en el país: López Obrador|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/2018/01/26/1216038|publisher =Excélsior|language=Spanish|date = 26 January 2018}}</ref>
López Obrador called for a change in security strategy and offered the controversial proposal of giving [[amnesty]] for drug dealers as a way to combat the drug cartels.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2018/05/03/mexico-candidate-amnesty-drug-dealers/570533002/|title=Amnesty for drug dealers? This Mexico presidential candidate is pushing for forgiveness|publisher=USA Today|author=David Agren|date=3 May 2018|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
During a debate in April, Rodríguez Calderón said "We have to cut off the hands of those who rob (in public service). It's that simple." He later explained that it was intended to be applied to both criminals and government functionaries involved in acts of corruption citing the application of this measure in [[Saudi Arabia]] as an example to reduce corruption and violence. Rodríguez Calderón was trending ahead of the other candidates on Twitter during the debate.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/cut-off-hands-mexican-presidential-candidates-plan-to-deter-thieves-40028884.html|title='Cut off hands': Mexican presidential candidate's plan to deter thieves|publisher=}}</ref>
Rodríguez Calderón later proposed to bring back the [[death penalty]] (currently constitutionally abolished in Mexico and enforced for the last time in 1961) for [[drug traffickers]], [[Aircraft hijacking|hijackers]], [[infanticide]]s and [[serial killer]]s.<ref>{{cite news |title =Ciudadanos quieren pena de muerte para narcos y asesinos, asegura ‘El Bronco’|url= https://www.reporteindigo.com/reporte/ciudadanos-quieren-pena-muerte-narcos-asesinos-asegura-bronco-video/|website=Reporte Indigo|accessdate=30 May 2018}}</ref>
==Controversies== ===Ballot access requirements=== The candidate put forward by the [[National Indigenous Congress]] and the [[Zapatista Army of National Liberation]], [[María de Jesús Patricio Martínez]] (Marichuy), alleged that the process for collecting signatures to attain ballot access unfairly benefits the rich. Marichuy said, "the INE made a list of telephone makes and models so that you must have at a minimum an Android 5.0 operating system or higher and so many hours to begin with the download of the applications in the devices, we find that the list is not true; we find brands that are not included in the list and of those that are included they don’t all work. The download is tedious and can take hours." The INE declared each signature registration would take 4.3 minutes, but each actual signature registration has taken up to 16 hours, or more. 'With these "classist, racist and excluding measures," Marichuy said, you realize "that this electoral system is not made for those peoples below that govern ourselves and that the laws and institutions of the State are made for those above, for the capitalists and their corrupt political class, resulting in a big simulation." Ultimately she was not able to obtain ballot access. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://chiapas-support.org/2017/10/23/marichuy-denounces-ines-system-for-collecting-signatures-via-cell-phone/|title=Marichuy denounces INE’s system for collecting signatures via cell phone|date=22 March 2018|accessdate=23 October 2017|website=chiapas-support.org}}</ref>
===PRI payments to Cambridge Analytica=== After the [[Facebook–Cambridge Analytica data scandal]], in April 2018, Forbes published information from the British news program [[Channel 4 News]] that had mentioned the existence of proof revealing ties between the PRI and Cambridge Analytica, suggesting a ''modus operandi'' similar to the one in the [[United States]]. The info said they worked together at least until January.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com.mx/cambridge-analytica-mexico-pri-enero-2018-channel-4-news/|title=Cambridge Analytica trabajó con el PRI: Channel 4 News • Forbes México|first=Forbes|last=Staff|date=30 March 2018|website=Forbes.com.mx|accessdate=9 April 2018}} </ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elfinanciero.com.mx/opinion/javier-murillo/cambridge-analytica-sigan-la-ruta-del-dinero|title=Cambridge Analytica, sigan la ruta del dinero|first=Javier|last=Murillo|website=Elfinanciero.com.mx|accessdate=9 April 2018}} </ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2018/03/22/inenglish/1521710735_571195.html|title=The distorted online networks of Mexico’s election campaign|first1=Fernando|last1=Peinado|first2=Elvira|last2=Palomo|first3=Javier|last3=Galán|date=22 March 2018|accessdate=9 April 2018|website=Elpais.com}}</ref> An investigation was requested.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.proceso.com.mx/528182/exigen-al-inai-investigar-a-cambridge-analytica-facebook-y-desarrolladoras-de-apps-en-mexico|title=Exigen al INAI investigar a Cambridge Analytica, Facebook y desarrolladoras de Apps en México - Proceso|date=2 April 2018|website=Proceso.com.mx|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> [[The New York Times]] obtained the 57 page proposal of Cambridge Analytica's proposed collaboration strategy to benefit the PRI by hurting MORENA's candidate Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador; the political party rejected the offer but still paid Cambridge Analytica to not help the other candidates.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/24/world/americas/mexico-election-cambridge-analytica.html|title=Mexico’s Hardball Politics Get Even Harder as PRI Fights to Hold On to Power|publisher=New York Times|date=24 June 2018|accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>
===Allegations of foreign intervention=== In April 2017, the [[US Secretary of Homeland Security]], [[John F. Kelly]], stated that the election of a [[Left-wing politics|left-wing]] president in Mexico "would not be good for America or Mexico". The statement was widely believed to be a reference to López Obrador, the leftist, frontrunner candidate, and created controversy in Mexico, as it seemed to be an attempt to influence the election against him.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/apr/5/trump-administration-wades-mexican-election/|work=The Washington Times|date=5 April 2017|first=Stephen|last=Dinan|title=Trump administration wades into Mexican election, warns against left-wing candidate|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-mexico-election/mexico-urges-respect-from-u-s-for-2018-presidential-election-idUSKBN1782O1|agency=Reuters|date=6 April 2017|title=Mexico urges respect from U.S. for 2018 presidential election|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mexico-protest-john-kelly-john-mccain-comments-about-leftist-election-2017-4|work=Business Insider|date=17 April 2017|title=Mexico wants John Kelly and John McCain to butt out of its election|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref>
In December 2017, [[National Security Advisor (United States)|US National Security Advisor]] [[H. R. McMaster]] claimed that [[Russia]] had launched a campaign to "influence Mexico’s 2018 presidential election and stir up division", without defining the methods of the supposed meddling, or indicating which would be the candidate favored by the Kremlin. The Russian government has denied the claims.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mexico-russia-usa/russia-meddling-in-mexican-election-white-house-aide-mcmaster-idUSKBN1EW0UD|agency=Reuters|date=7 January 2018|title=Russia meddling in Mexican election: White House aide McMaster|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref> [[Institutional Revolutionary Party|PRI]] president [[:es:Enrique Ochoa Reza|Enrique Ochoa Reza]] claimed that "Russian and Venezuelan interests" are supporting López Obrador's campaign.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/518252/intereses-de-rusia-y-venezuela-apoyan-lopez-pri|work=Proceso|date=12 January 2018|title=Intereses de Rusia y Venezuela apoyan a "López": PRI|language=Spanish|accessdate=14 January 2018}}</ref>
López Obrador responded that Ochoa's declarations are part of a [[smear campaign]] against him,<ref name="Aristegui Noticias"/> and later posted a video via social media, where he joked about the claims and called himself "Andres Manuelovich".<ref name="reuters.com"/><ref name="aristeguinoticias.com"/>
[[Guatemala]]n right-wing commentator [[Gloria Álvarez]] embarked on a tour through Mexico, calling López Obrador a "dangerous populist" and urging citizens not to vote for him. She was invited to a PAN legislators assembly on 31 January, where she criticized the alliance with the PRD, which she called "a party just like MORENA".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.milenio.com/politica/populismo-partidos_politicos-prd-amlo-politologa-milenio-noticias_0_1039696255.html|work=Milenio|date=31 January 2018|title=Preparación académica, la mejor arma contra el populismo: politóloga|language=Spanish|accessdate=30 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/elecciones-2018/critican-en-plenaria-panistas-por-aliarse-al-prd|work=El Universal|date=31 January 2018|title=Critican en plenaria a panistas por aliarse al PRD|language=Spanish|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref>
[[US Senator]]s [[Bob Menendez]] and [[Marco Rubio]] asked [[US Secretary of State]] [[Rex Tillerson]] to "fight Russian meddling" in the Mexican elections.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/371583-senators-ask-tillerson-to-fight-russian-interference-in-mexico-election|work=TheHill|date=31 January 2018|title=Senators ask Tillerson to fight Russian interference in Mexico election: report|accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> On 2 February during a summit in Mexico, Tillerson stated that Mexico should "beware the Russian interference".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/r-tillerson-warns-mexico-to-watch-russian-election-meddling-2018-2|work=Business Insider|date=2 February 2018|title=Tillerson warns Mexico to watch Russian election meddling|accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> Dr. Tony Payan, director of the Mexico Center at [[Rice University]] noted that there was no evidence of actual Russian tampering in the Mexican electoral process, and considered the accusations "absurd" given that the Trump administration "will not admit Russia interfered in the US election".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/russia-meddling-mexico-election-rex-tillerson-marco-rubio-bob-menendez-senators-a8188286.html|work=The Independent|date=2 February 2018|title=Rex Tillerson urged to raise Russian meddling in Mexico election on upcoming trip to region|accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref>
===Possibility of election tampering=== [[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]] warned about the possibility of the PRI committing [[electoral fraud]], with Tony Payan, director of the Mexico Center at [[Rice University]]’s Baker Institute in [[Houston]], United States, suggesting that both vote buyout and computer hackings were possible and citing irregularities in the 1988 electoral process. Bloomberg's article also suggested Meade could be receiving unfair help from the over-budget amounts of money spent on publicity by incumbent president [[Enrique Peña Nieto]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-18/mexico-s-biggest-election-could-turn-dirty-it-s-happened-before|title=Mexico’s Presidential Election Could Get Really Dirty|date=18 December 2017|accessdate=9 April 2018|website=Bloomberg.com}}</ref>
Additionally, Meade spent more money on pre-campaign efforts than López Obrador and Anaya together, while failing to report where his funds came from; in contrast, López Obrador has attended the most events while spending the least money and successfully reported better than his rivals where he obtained the resources to pay for those events.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://aristeguinoticias.com/0301/mexico/meade-no-reporta-ingresos-ante-ine-y-gasta-mas-del-doble-que-anaya-y-amlo-juntos/|title=Meade reporta más del doble de gastos que Anaya y López Obrador en precampañas - Aristegui Noticias|website=aristeguinoticias.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
====Prior PRI election tampering controversies in 2017==== During 2017, the PRI had faced allegations of electoral fraud concerning the election of Peña Nieto's cousin [[Alfredo del Mazo Maza]] as Governor of the [[state of Mexico]]. Despite the official vote results given by the INE (Electoral National Institute) giving the win to del Mazo, the election was marred by irregularities including reports of vote-buying,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://eleconomista.com.mx/sociedad/2017/06/04/denuncian-compra-votos-favor-alfredo-mazo|work=El Economista|date=4 June 2017|first=Leopoldo|last=Hernández|title=Denuncian compra de votos a favor de Alfredo del Mazo|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> spending beyond legal campaign finance limits,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/08-06-2017/3236142|work=SinEmbargo|date=8 June 2017|first=Dulce|last=Olvera|title=Del Mazo gastó 412 millones 225 mil en Edomex, cuando sólo podía disponer de 285 millones: Morena|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> and electoral counts that gave del Mazo extra votes that awarded the election to him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/07-06-2017/3235335|date=7 June 2017|accessdate=9 June 2017|title=El PREP sumó al PRI 238 mil 145 votos de más en el Edomex, con los que da ventaja a Del Mazo|work=SinEmbargo}}</ref> In November 2017, left-wing magazine ''[[Proceso (magazine)|Proceso]]'' published an article accusing the PRI of breaking at least 16 state laws during the elections, which were denounced 619 times. They said that all of them were broken in order to favor del Mazo during the election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/511392/ni-libre-ni-autentica-la-eleccion-en-edomex-ni-fraude|title="Ni libre, ni auténtica”, la elección en Edomex: Ni un Fraude Más - Proceso|date=16 November 2017|website=Proceso.com.mx|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
==Results==
===President=== López Obrador won the election on 1 July 2018 with over 50% of the popular vote. In terms of states won, López Obrador won in a landslide, carrying 31 out of 32 of [[States of Mexico|the country's states]],<ref name="ReutersMurray" /> the most states won by a candidate since [[Ernesto Zedillo]] won every state in the [[Mexican general election, 1994|1994 election]].
Around 30 minutes after polls closed in the country's north-west, José Antonio Meade, speaking at a news conference from PRI headquarters, conceded defeat and wished López Obrador "every success".<ref>{{cite news |title=Jose Antonio Meade of Mexico's ruling party concedes defeat to Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador in presidential vote |url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/jose-antonio-meade-mexicos-ruling-party-concedes-defeat-56306465 |accessdate=1 July 2018 |agency=ABC News (USA) |date=1 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Le deseo el mayor de los éxitos a AMLO: Meade |url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/le-deseo-el-mayor-de-los-exitos-a-amlo-meade/1249456 |accessdate=1 July 2018 |publisher=''[[Excélsior]]'' |date=1 July 2018}}</ref>
Ricardo Anaya also conceded defeat within an hour of the polls closing,<ref>{{cite news |title=Anaya reconoce victoria de AMLO |url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/elecciones-2018/ricardo-anaya-reconoce-victoria-de-amlo |accessdate=1 July 2018 |publisher=''[[El Universal (Mexico City)]]'' |date=1 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Mexico election: Exit polls put López Obrador in front |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-44677829 |accessdate=1 July 2018 |agency=BBC News |date=1 July 2018}}</ref> and independent candidate Jaime Rodríguez Calderón recognized López Obrador's victory shortly afterward.<ref>{{cite news |last1=García |first1=Aracely |title=‘El Bronco’ reconoce triunfo de López Obrador |url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/el-bronco-reconoce-triunfo-de-lopez-obrador/1249467 |accessdate=1 July 2018 |publisher=''[[Excélsior]]'' |date=1 July 2018}}</ref>
The results of the INE's official [[quick count]] were announced around midnight Mexico City time. It reported a turnout of around 63%, with the following approximate results for the candidates: López Obrador, 53%; Anaya, 22%; Meade, 16%; and Rodríguez Calderón, 5%. This is the first time since [[Mexican general election, 1988|the (controversial) 1988 election]] that a presidential candidate was elected with an absolute majority (50%+1) of the votes cast.<ref>{{cite news |title=Conteo rápido del INE da victoria a Andrés Manuel López Obrador |url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/elecciones-2018/conteo-rapido-del-ine-da-victoria-andres-manuel-lopez-obrador |accessdate=1 July 2018 |publisher=''[[El Universal (Mexico City)]]'' |date=1 July 2018}}</ref>

[https://www.mnd.gov.tw/English/ www.mnd.gov.tw/English/] {{en icon}} |footnotes = }} The '''Ministry of National Defense of the Republic of China''' ('''MND'''; {{zh |t = 中華民國國防部 |p = Zhōnghuá Mínguó Guófángbù |poj=Tiong-hoâ Bîn-kok Kok-hông-pō͘}}) is a [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]]-level agency under the [[Executive Yuan]] responsible for all [[National security|defense]] and [[military]] affairs of Taiwan. The MND is headed by Minister [[Yen Teh-fa]]. == History == [[File:ROC-MND Boai Building 20100101.jpg|thumb|ROC Ministry of National Defense former headquarters]] The MND was originally established as '''Ministry of War''' in 1912 at the creation of the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]]. It was changed to the '''Ministry of National Defense''' in 1946. The Law of National Defense and the Organic Law of the ministry were officially promulgated for implementation on 1 March 2002.{{cite web| url = http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/taiwan/mnd.htm|title=Ministry of National Defense |author=John Pike |website = globalsecurity.org}} On 8 December 2014, the ministry moved out from its building from the previous one at Boai Building in [[Zhongzheng District]] to the current one in Dazhi area at [[Zhongshan District, Taipei|Zhongshan District]], where it houses the Air Force Command Headquarters, Navy Command Headquarters and Hengshan Military Command Center.{{cite web |url = http://focustaiwan.tw/news/aipl/201412050031.aspx |title = Defense Ministry's new compound to be officially opened Dec. 8 |website = focustaiwan.tw}} The completion of the building had been delayed for nearly two decades due to the compound original architecture and the bankruptcy of the project's original contractor. The planning for the new building and relocation had been done since 1997.{{cite web|url=http://focustaiwan.tw/news/asoc/201412080026.aspx|title=Defense minister raises flag at new ministry compound|work=focustaiwan.tw}} The official ribbon-cutting ceremony was held on 27 December 2014.{{cite web|url=http://focustaiwan.cna.com.tw/news/aipl/201412270020.aspx|title=Defense Ministry's new headquarters officially opens|work=cna.com.tw}} == Headquarters== [[File:Ministry of National Defence Dazhi New Site Front View 20120930.jpg|thumb|ROC Ministry of National Defense headquarters]] The headquarters of the military was originally in eastern [[Nanjing]] near [[Ming Palace]]. Today it is located in Dazhi area of [[Zhongshan District, Taipei|Zhongshan District]] in [[Taipei]]. The 8-story main building was constructed at a cost of NT$15.8 billion, spreading over 19.5 hectares of area, which houses office buildings, dormitories and other facilities, such as post office, barbershop, sports center, conference hall and sport center to accommodate its 3,000 military personnel stationed there. It also includes several annex buildings around.{{cite web |url = http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2014/12/28/2003607766 |title = Taipei military complex opened |website = taipeitimes.com}} The security features of the building include fingerprint and eye scanners that restrict access to certain areas, sensors that can detect vehicles in the unauthorized areas and that may carry explosives and [[bollards]] on the compound to block unauthorized vehicles. The compound also has eco-friendly features, such as stone walls, aluminum and low-emission exterior glass panels. The central [[air conditioning]] system is provided by [[Ice storage air conditioning|ice storage system]] to reduce peak load electricity demand. The building also has rainwater collecting facilities which can store up to 1,000 tons of water, complete with its waste water treatment and filtering systems. ==Budget== The current annual defense budget for Taiwan is NT$320 billion.{{cite web|url=http://focustaiwan.tw/news/aipl/201606070027.aspx|title=Difficult to set defense budget at 3% of GDP: premier - Politics - FOCUS TAIWAN - CNA ENGLISH NEWS|publisher=}} == Organizational structure == [[File:ROC-MND Armed Forces Reserve Command 20160816.jpg|thumb|[[Armed Forces Reserve Command]]]] [[File:ROCAF Dazhi Headquarters 20120701.jpg|thumb|Air Force Command Headquarters]] [[File:ROC-MND National Defense Procurement Office 20131118.jpg|thumb|National Defense Procurement Office]] [[File:ROC-MND Armaments Bureau 20131012.jpg|thumb|[[Armaments Bureau]]]] === Military institutions === * Armed Forces Reserve Command (後備指揮部) * Military Police Command (憲兵指揮部) === Military authorities === * Army Command Headquarters (陸軍司令部) * Navy Command Headquarters (海軍司令部) * Air Force Command Headquarters (空軍司令部) === Headquarter departments === * Department of Strategic Planning (戰略規劃司) * Department of Resources Planning (資源規劃司) * Department of Military Justice (法律事務司) * Department of Integrated Assessment (整合評估司) * Office of the Inspector General (總督察長室) * All-out Defense Mobilization Office (全民防衛動員室) * National Defense Procurement Office (國防採購室) * National Defense Technology Division (國防科技處, after 1 January 2017){{cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2016/10/12/2003656993|title=Defense ministry confirms new agency -
